Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
The Canon PowerShot S95 is a compact digital camera that's perfect for travellers or even photography enthusiasts who want a small camera with manual controls.
It's very small, yet it's designed to allow you to change the exposure almost as quickly as you could with a digital SLR. If you don't want to change the exposure settings manually, the Canon PowerShot S95 has an auto mode and plenty of scene modes to help you get the most out of it straight away.
The Canon PowerShot S95 is the type of compact camera you buy when you absolutely must have something that will be very easy to carry around, yet also be capable of capturing very good quality images at a moment's notice. We think it's perfect to take on holiday or on a work trip as it can be used effectively in all kinds of ... lighting situations.
Canon PowerShot S95: Specifications
It has a 10-megapixel CCD sensor, but at 1/1.7in, it's slightly bigger than the CCD sensor in a typical compact camera such as the Canon PowerShot SX210 IS, which has a 1/2.3in sensor. The Canon PowerShot S95 has the same sensor size as other advanced compact cameras such as Samsung's EX1, but it's a smidgin smaller than the 1/1.63in sensor that can be found in Panasonic's LUMIX DMC-LX3 and LX5. The slightly larger sensor allows more light to be captured, which means that overall the camera can produce more vibrant images than a typical compact.
Sitting in front of the sensor is a 28-105mm zoom lens with an aperture of f/2.0, which is nice and wide for capturing images in low-light situations. It closes to f/4.9 when you zoom in all the way, and the smallest size you can use is f/8.0. Its star-shaped diaphragm renders lights with a lovely star burst–like effect, which can look good when capturing reflections during the day and streetlights during the night, for example.
The lens' diaphragm renders lights and reflections with a lovely star burst shape.
The Canon PowerShot S95 camera's shutter speed isn't overly quick; it only goes as fast as 1/1600th of a second, but it can slow down to 15sec for night shoots. We would have liked it to shut at least as fast as 1/2000th of a second, which is a speed that most compacts can achieve. Still, this isn't too much of an inconvenience and we had no problems using the S95 on very bright days. At the other end of the scale, we would have liked the shutter to be able to stay open for a least one minute for tasks such as capturing lightning or fireworks at night. (There is a fireworks scene mode, but it only keeps the shutter open for two seconds.)
Canon PowerShot S95: Picture quality
A night scene as captured using aperture priority mode with a aperture of f/2.0 and an ISO of 100.
Image quality is very good. Pictures are captured clearly and with accurate colour tones; when it's in auto and semi-auto modes, the camera does a good job of properly exposing each scene. Even difficult scenes featuring both highlights and dark shadows were captured accurately. The camera has a good handle on noise up to around ISO 400, but we'd recommend using as low an ISO as possible, as pictures will start to look too grainy above that figure. With the wide aperture, a high ISO isn't always needed anyway.
Colours are rendered accurately and aren't overdone. This was taken in a shaded area.
Even at their full size, images retain their clarity and you can make out fine details.
The Canon PowerShot S95 is accurate and versatile when it comes to focusing, but it's only accurate if you want to focus on a subject in the central parts of the frame. You can use tracking mode to lock on to subjects and then bring them to the side of the frame if you want to give your photos are more interesting perspective. This worked very well in our tests and we're also pleased with the amount of background blur that occurs with a wide aperture of f/2.0.
We used tracking mode focus to bring Tux to the right side of the frame. The camera kept focus even as we moved closer to him.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: No-nonsense design is easily pocketed Bright, optically stabilized wide-angle zoom with very good image quality New Hybrid IS system corrects for both lateral shifts and angular motion Programmable control ring Shortcut button works great to quickly set Custom White Balance Bracketing is fast and easy Very good color accuracy Better than average noise performance Faster JPEG burst mode than S90 (but still sluggish) RAW support 720p HD movies with stereo sound i-Contrast with highlight and shadow adjustments HDR mode (but requires use of tripod) Variable AF frame size AF-point zoom Tracking AF Improved Control Dial position reduces accidental activation My Menu for commonly used settings Smile Shutter and Face Self-timer SDXC ca ... rd support Excellent print quality, outputting 13x19-inch prints from ISO 80 to 400
Cons: Generally sluggish performance overall No noise reduction options High geometric distortion at wide-angle in uncorrected RAWs Moderate chromatic aberration at wide-angle Optical zoom and AF not supported during movies Lens doesn't go as wide as some of the competition Slow flash recycling Auto flash can select slow shutter speeds Below average battery life (slightly worse than S90) Lacking some features that competitors have (no hand-held multi-shot modes, no automatic panorama feature, etc.) Needs some kind of grip Exposure information isn't present or updated until you half-press the shutter button Trouble with heavy noise suppression in certain reds
Fresh off reviewing the Panasonic LX5, I'm impressed by the similarities between it and the Canon PowerShot S95. Both have a 3.8x, f/2.0, image-stabilized lens, a 3-inch LCD, a 10-megapixel sensor, a pop-up flash, a zoom toggle surrounding the shutter button, and more dials than the average pocket digital camera. Of course, there are differences as well. The Canon S95's focal length ranges from 28-105mm, while the LX5's covers a wider 24-90mm. The S95's LCD is a 4:3 aspect ratio, while the LX5's is 3:2. The Canon S95 is also smaller and has no hot shoe, while it does have a unique reprogrammable front Control Ring. They are both aimed at the premium pocket market, and also differ only slightly from their predecessors. For its part, the Canon S95 is improved in some important ways. *Look and feel*. Canon did a great job making the S95 compact, yet with a bright lens and larger sensor than the average digital camera. Dressed all in black, the boldest element of the Canon S95 is the bright white Canon logo, embossed just as it is on the company's digital SLRs. Everything else appears military-grade, designed for stealth, perfect for street photography. Even the S95 logo the font around the lens barrel are a dark gray, unlike the S90's bright white. Other than that, little has changed on the front of the S95, except that the microphone hole has been replaced with microphone holes at the lower left and right of the lens to accommodate the Canon S95's stereo audio recording with the new 720p HD movie mode. The Canon S95's lens flange does protrude more than the company's other pocket cameras, but that's understandable, and in this case, useful. The knurled ring surrounding the lens is the multi-purpose Control Ring, which you can reprogram by pressing the Ring Function button next to the Power button. These two buttons, incidentally, are now put in their right positions, with the power button beside the shutter button, where we've been trained to expect it. With the S90, I very often hit the Ring Function button when I'd intended to power off the camera. The Canon S95 has no grip, but the texture of the camera is a little rougher to improve the grip. It's not a significant improvement, though, so if it's difficult for you to hold, consider an aftermarket stick-on grip. More on this, and how it affects the overall use of the camera, later. In the upper left corner of the top, you see the cutout for the flash. Unlike the LX5, the Canon S95's flash comes up under motorized power, and is deployed when the camera decides to, either because the light is too... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Although the S95 is only a small improvement over the already excellent S90, the combination of small improvements do add up to a significantly better camera. Overall performance could still use some improvement, but creative versatility and more importantly image quality, especially in low light, are as good as it currently gets. TrustedReviews Awards logo Best Advanced Compact Digital Camera In nature it is competition that drives the process of evolution. As species compete for limited resources they evolve over time to become better adapted to the needs of their environment. The same evolutionary process operates in the world of digital cameras. Manufacturers compete for the resource of your spending money, and the evolutionary result is ever more sophisticated cameras, with better per ... formance, better image quality and more advanced features. There are few better examples of this than the long-running rivalry between Canon and Panasonic in the specialised environment of advanced enthusiast's compact cameras. Canon PowerShot S95 front angle Last year saw the re-launch of Canon's advanced PowerShot S-series in the shape of the S90, an advanced compact featuring the same 10-megapixel sensor as Canon's flagship at the time, the PowerShot G11. The S90 was Canon's response to the success of Panasonic's superb Lumix LX3, itself a successor to 2006's LX1, which had been introduced to compete with the S90's predecessor, Canon's PowerShot S80, launched in 2005. These competitions can get complicated. Panasonic has recently launched the latest in the LX line, the excellent Lumix LX5, so it will come as little surprise that Canon has also launched its latest competitor, the PowerShot S95. Like Panasonic, Canon has only made small changes and upgrades to the S90 to produce the new camera, but the cumulative effect is a significant improvement over the older model. Canon PowerShot S95 front Although the S95 and the LX5 look very different they are actually very similar cameras in many respects. Both have 10-megapixel sensors of a larger size than those found in most current compacts (1/1.7-in for the S95 and 1/1.63-in for the LX5). Both have high-quality 3.8x zoom lenses with fast f/2 maximum aperture, both have 7.5cm (3.0-in) LCD monitors with 460k resolution. Both offer a full range of manual exposure options, both shoot 720p HD video (although the S95 does so with stereo audio) and both have pop-up flash units. Even more importantly both cameras are currently have a high street price of £399. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
The Canon Powershot S95 was released a little over a year after its predecessor, the Canon S90, was announced.
Building on a legacy of quality premium compact cameras, and with more and more entering the market, Canon have a lot to compete with nowadays, so does the Canon S95 still hold muster?
Update: See our video review below
Improvements on the Canon S95 include the addition of the HS system, a combination of a high-sensitivity 10.0 megapixel CCD sensor and DIGIC 4 processor, promising optimised low-light shooting. Manual control has also been upgraded, while HD movie recording has been added.
For the first time in a compact, Canon's Hybrid IS technology which provides image stabilisation has also been incorporated. It's brought over the ability to shoot i ... n RAW, the useful ring-control system and the same 6-22.5mm (35mm equivalent: 28-105mm) f/2.0 lens. In short, you're getting a fair old bang for your buck.
Bearing in mind that physically the Canon S95 is more or less the same as the PowerShot S90 (it's a touch smaller than the S90 and now uses the same coating as found on the Canon 7D semi-pro DSLR in a bid to improve grip), first impressions of the camera are good.
The sleek body and metal finish lend it air of class, while its miniature size belies its impressive stats. The little brother of the Canon G12, this is probably one of the only high-end compacts on the market that is truly pocketable. As well as adding to the sleek design, it's nice not to have a fiddly lenscap to keep track of such as on the likes of the Panasonic LX5. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Point and Shoot for Film Photographer
Item.Review: I work all day in front of a computer so when I pick up a camera, I typically like to shoot film. It's a break from my work day but also I adore the aesthetic quality of film. I have a Hasselblad 500c and Leica R4. In the past have tinkered with digital point and shoots but I have bad luck with them breaking and what not. So I decided to finally invest in another digital camera and portable case (Lowepro D-Wrap). Here's some of the things I immediately liked about this camera... -Compact: Beats lugging around the Hasselblad and it's pocket size makes it great to take to any event. -RAW Format: This is one of the major perks my co-workers highlighted when I ask their opinion on digital point and shoots (I work at a photo center). -Manual focusing option: I was surprised when I discovere ... d this, but pleasantly so. -Overall Image Quality: So far I have been pretty impressed with this little guy. Shooting in both Manual and Auto modes, I am happy with color management on this camera. I have yet to print any of the image so I might have a follow up report when I do. Things that I wish were different... Flash Placement: If you hold this camera like most people hold small digital cameras you will most likely end up placing your left hand index finger directly over the on retractable on camera flash. This is annoying when flash is in auto mode and you end up smashing it with your hand. No View Finder: In the past I will by pass the rear LCD when my battery is low and use the good old fashion view finder. Alas this camera does not have one. My last digital camera got in a fight with my Hasselblad in my camera bag which resulted in a smashed LCD. It too had no view finder so I haphazardly shot with no idea of what I was capturing. A little Slow: The cycle time between shots feels a little slow. Lack of contour to Body: This is just my general paranoia kicking in, but I have a history of being clumsy. I worry since this camera is so strealine (even the buttons manage to be almost flush to the body) that I will drop it easily. I readied this with the Lowepro D-Wrap which remains attached to the camera body even while shooting adding an additional area to hold on to. We shall see. I have only had this camera a little while and I am interested to see how my relationship unfolds. expand » « collapse
Item.HelpfulCount: 1 out of 1 found this review helpful.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I doubt this camera will be available for too much longer as the new models come out, so if you're in the market for a good quality pocket camera, add this one to your arsenal. I would go as far as to say this is a MUST HAVE for any serious point and shooter, especially if you're a Canon fan. I just bought my second one this week from B&H, just to have a back-up in case I lose my other one. Good price now too. A few main things I like about the camera that are most important to me: It has fast, accurate autofocus (at all distances) down to macro. It doesn't get fooled too often. Superb, SLR quality manual control, Excellent lens, it's great having F/2 for low light. F/4 is the lens' sweet spot, best resolution. F/5.6 is good for best overall IQ with moderate depth of field. F/8 has ... really crisp DOF out to 2 feet, and maybe a little beyond. It's a good indoor camera for documenting hobby projects and close-up work. It's obviously a great outdoor camera too, does macro flowers well, but don't count on the big F/2 aperture to deliver the bokeh you get with an SLR. It's still a small sensor camera. The zoom is modest, but it's really sharp at mid range to max telephoto, even edge to edge. At wide angle resolution is awesome for a small camera, but sharpness falls off a tiny bit in the far corners, as do most small wide angles. No complaints about this lens. It has a really beautiful, sharp LCD screen too, almost too pretty. It has a slightly larger sensor than an average compact???1/1.7 with an appropriate 10 MP that delivers excellent color and image quality. And again, 10 Mega Pixels with a compact camera is perfect. (Less is more???too true) It's a really well made camera and just feels solid, almost heavy. The menu is a typical Canon layout, very intuitive. (I think Canon, and Nikon, have the best menus in the business) The S95's controls feel really high quality and precise. It's like a small fine tool???one of Canon's finest products. Main Gripe: It's harder on batteries than my other Canon cameras (like my SD980), using the same NB-6L Li-ion. People are probably tired of hearing me say this, but if the S95 used AA batteries (Ultimate Lithiums) it would be the perfect camera. And AA's would be a good reason for Canon to give it a bulging grip to house those batteries. COOL!!! There are personal reasons why I decided to go ahead and buy another S95 instead of waiting for its S100 replacement. Mostly, I just like the controls on the S95 better. And it's 10MP too. The S100 will have the new DIGIC 5 processor though. So we'll see??? expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I wanted a small camera that would shoot RAW when it's not practical to carry my DSLR. This is it. Pocket-sized and 10 MP with RAW format available. Though the sensor is certainly smaller than 4/3 or APS-C, it is still a bit larger than the typical pocket-sized point-and-shoot cameras. I've only had it for a couple weeks but have found the images to be sharp and the colors to be rich. It's too early to evaluate battery life. Since I'm not a video guy I can't comment on that either. There are many settings on this camera so if you're looking for control this could be what you want. If you're just looking for simple point-and-shoot, this is definitely much more than you will ever need so save the money and get something cheaper.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Longtime Canon P&S user, not impressed
Item.Review: I picked this camera up on a great 2011 Christmas special. I have been happy using an Canon 870IS for several years, and more recently a Canon 300HS. I was pretty excited to finally get a P&S that shoots RAW. However, not all modes support RAW capture which was a HUGE disappointment. The primary reason for RAW for me was to get around the horrible smaller sensor in camera JPG rendering. I work in the professional printing industry and my primary camera is a Nikon D300S with mostly prime lenses. While ISO performance as very good. Overall image quality was not significantly better than the 300HS under most indoor shooting conditions. Which is the main use for a point and shoot IMO. Canon now requires five button presses to delete an image. I often like to delete photos in came ... ra so that I don't have to transfer or sort them later. (Nikon's let you chose between two quick presses or 4.) Much better video than Nikon or Olympus competitors. The size is great, and ergonomics wasn't as nice as the 300HS IMO. Even if you get a great deal on this camera Canon's models selling for half the price will serve most people's needs better. I've researched every camera in this range and there is always a tradeoff. When you get into the five hundred dollar price range you might as well get an entry level DSLR. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Let's just assume this camera takes good pictures for what it is and that the price is good given it's size/portability vs. the competition. I think some of the features in the software are dumb. I also like to shoot B&W and think I should be able to turn it on no matter what mode I'm in but the camera doesn't seem to do that, or, I just can't figure it out. User manual on CD is lame; please provide a printed book. Personally I think the battery life is pretty decent. I bought the Pearstone spare and the charging time is quite good for both batteries. Mainly it's just the limited, or possibly difficult to access, B&W which really frustrates me about this camera. I think B&W should be a default button or super easy to access in any mode at any time. Otherwise I like it. LCD ... is quite good. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: They've really done it right with this camera. I justified buying this camera because I have a background in photography, although it's been a while since I've had decent still photography equipment. I told my wife that it would pay for itself if I could take my new daughter's yearly portraits with it. I knew I would be using a slave flash. With a lot of trial and error, I was able to get some usable photos. I wish they had a way to trigger a flash without using the on-board flash. It's a great size for all the features. At first, I thought the control ring around the lens was too bulky, and thought it stuck out of the camera too much. Of course that is the idea. It only took me a couple of days to get used to it and compared to a larger DSLR, it's wonderful. I also missed the viewfinde ... r at first. I'm kinda used to them, but the screen is so nice, that it's easy to live without it. While the mode wheel seems very high quality, it is a little stiff to turn. I'll take it over a cheap-feeling knob. I only wish it had a GPS chip for geolocation metadata... I might have paid an extra $50-75 for that. I wish it had a different color tally light for taking video. This goes for any camera. That way people aren't constantly wondering if you're taking a picture or video footage. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Appearance/Size/Form FactorCompared to other cameras in the advanced compact category, the S95 is tiny. The S95 can easily slip into your pants pocket without anyone asking you is that a camera in your pocket or are you just happy to see me?. If a compact camera body is one of your major requirements, the S95 should be at the top of your list.One plus the S95 has over its predecessor (the S90) is its textureized body. The S90 felt like a wet bar of soap which is not a characteristic I look for in a camera. This rubbery/grippy texture allows the user to gain a sold grip on the camera which is important when dealing with a camera this small. The S95 feels good in your hand although I do wish it had more of a physical grip similar to the Panasonic LX-5; I assume Canon decided against a grip t ... o keep the body as slim and sleek as possible. I'm not too worried about the lack of grip as there are a few third party options to remedy this complaint e.g. Richard Franiec's custom grip.I'm not sure what people consider a good looking camera, but the S95 looks good to me. The all black body with silver lettering is a color scheme that should be familiar to most. The display takes up the majority of the real-estate on the back of the camera which is a good thing because it is a pleasure to use. Colors are bright and blacks look decent as well. My only complaint with the display, which is common among most point and shoot cameras, is it easily becomes washed out in bright sunlight. This is when I really wish Canon had offered an optional EVF for the S95.ControlsEasy access to controls is where the S95 really jumps ahead of the competition. I hate digging through levels of menus or having to cycle down a list of features just to change the ISO. Give me physical buttons! Luckily there are two dials on the S95, one in the front and one in the back of the camera. These dials allow the user to easily change the most frequently needed settings.Like it's older sibling, the S95 has a control ring around the lens which gives you quick access to settings like aperture, shutter speed, focal length, etc. The control ring has default settings based on which mode you are in but the control ring's function can easily be changed by a physical button on the top of the camera.On the back of the back of the camera is another function ring. By default, this ring is setup to manage the functions which are available by pushing on the top, bottom, left and right or the ring. I would say 99% of the time I use this ring to manage exposure compensation. The other 1% of the time it is used to manage shutter speed while I'm in Manual mode???I prefer to shoot in Aperture Priority when using the S95.Along with the dials is a programmable button on the back of the camera which can be assigned by the user; I have mine set to pull up the ISO. This can be set to a myriad of different functions like white balance or file type, but I find that setting this to ISO really gives me quick access to the essentials for getting a solid exposure.FeaturesLike any new camera, there are a million features that the S95 brings to the game. I could list them all here, but you would probably have better luck looking at a product page. To keep it short, I'll list a few of my favorite features of this camera:ISO max for auto ISO: Most new advanced point and shoot cameras have an auto ISO setting. The problem with this is not all of them give you a limit as to how high the camera will go when choosing an ISO setting. Thankfully, the S95 does. I personally like to set my ISO manually, but this is a nice feature if you are a beginner or if you just want to shoot and not worry about settings.Interval timer with shot # selection: This is something I wish my old 5D had. Not only can you select the shutter timer duration, you can also select how many shots in succession the S95 will take after the timer goes off. I could see this feature being helpful for family portraits or landscapes.Bright Lens: With a bright f/2.0 lens and IS, the S95 works surprisingly well in low-light conditions.... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Great pictures, easy to use, great features
Cons: No viewfinder
This camera is incredible. I bought it after playing around with one that a coworker had bought for us to use here, and I can't say how impressed I am with it after owning it for about a month. My time to learn how to use it was during a wedding in India. The pictures turned out to be absolutely gorgeous, and I took over 500 pictures and videos of the event.
First, the picture quality is great. It's a great camera and has taken some super cool shots. The lens is really nice, and the ability to do fine-tune adjustment of the focus using the wheel on the front is really cool. The wheel on the back can also be used to tweak an image, and the combination of the two is fantastic. We blew up one of the pic ... tures of the Taj Mahal that we took on the highest resolution and it looks like a professional photograph. I'm supremely confident that should we print up a painting size for this that it will look awesome.
The features on this camera are phenomenal. I took pictures using the "Antique" mode, and it looked like we were at the Taj Mahal in the 1920's. Using the "Color Accent" option, I got some really incredible shots of some of the festivities - highlighting just the red in the Henna ceremony, or selecting one color of the numerous Saaris. "Vivid" was hardly needed as the colors popped on their own, and admittedly this looked a little too over-saturated. The "Miniaturize" feature is also very cool, and takes some really neat artsy shots by blurring the top and bottom edge of the photo. All of these features have things that you can tweak using the ring on the front or the wheel on the back. The low-light setting was also great for night-time shots where you don't want the flash to go off every 3 seconds.
The camera is extremely easy to use. It has a setting for full auto and makes it a point and shoot. The camera comes up and is ready to take a picture extremely fast, and the continuous shooting is also very easy to set up. All in all, I spent about 30 minutes (which i ... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Bought this camera for both the photo and video features. As filmmakers, my husband and I like to have something small in our pockets at all times to sketch out ideas, scout locations, and create short films. Though only 720p, the image quality on the videos is absolutely outstanding. The lag (in video modes) on the autofocus and autoexposure is very tolerable. I can already say we'll use this more than our flip cam because the image quality is superior. The miniature feature is also a fun effect that I would actually use (not a common thing in regard to built-in effects). The photos are comparably sharp and the colors rich, even in low light. I'm a big fan of slightly saturated color though, so if you want something 100% natural, you may need to do some correcting later. The body ... design and the ring for changing settings on the front gives this camera a fantastic feel! If you're used to an SLR like me, you'll feel at home with this little guy. Haven't really paid much attention to the audio. I carry a little Tascam digital recorder around for that, so it didn't play into my decision to buy. The only con: The placement of the power button makes it really easy to press on accident. Overall it's the perfect pocket camera for creative professionals who like to be prepared for great quality images & videos on the fly. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Fast lense, great high ISO performance, IS
Cons: No ACR support (RAW), turn-on time is somewhat slow, flash control
I am not sure if I will own this camera (S95) after the 14-day return period. This is due to my G9 failing due to a major design/manufacturing flaw and Canon refusing to accept responsibility. Google "G9 loose screw". The G-series cameras self destruct. You end up with a $500 paperweight. Canon refuses to acknowledge any issue AT ALL. There are hundreds, if not thousands, of cases posted on the internet. I am pretty disgusted with Canon at this point, since my Canon DSLR investment is well into the five figures. No 5D Mark II at this point to use with my 20D and 40D. All future equipment purchases are on hold.
The S95 is a sweet camera that I purcha ... sed to replace/compliment both my SD550 and G9. I have created about 30 DVDs worth of video from the two cameras of my five year old daughter. Between videos and photos, I will not go without a carry everywhere camera. A cell phone does not work as an acceptable substitute.
I bought the S95 (instead of S90 earlier) mainly due to the addition of 720 video. The f/2.0 lense is sweet, and having IS finally on my small P&S (not on my SD550) is great too. I have done handheld shots at 1/5 on the G9 with great results.
The controls in manual work very well. The ring around the lense does aperture, the main control dial does shutter speed and then I programmed the print button to do ISO. One reason I will never buy a Canon Rebel DSLR is due to the lack of two control dials in manual. The little P&S has two!
Two issues I have right now concern my video and photo PP workflow. Canon does NOT support the S95 in ACR. The DPP software just flatout sucks. Also, my normal video editing/burning methods are not supported with 720, so that will require a software upgrade. I normally shoot RAW + small jpg with the jpg used only for TV or quick reference viewing. I have started shooting the S95 in RAW + full jpg, with the RAWs getting archived for later work. I edit the jpgs in ACR (CS3). Works great, but the control of shadows and highli ... expand » « collapse
Item.HelpfulCount: 0 out of 1 found this review helpful.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: This is the best pocket camera I've owned - and I have owned many. It is not a simple point and shoot camera, although it can be used as such. Picture quality is just about on par with my Nikon D300, and the camera's RAW format makes it possible for you to maximize all of your post-processing routines and procedures. It's versatility lies in its ability to adjust all of the settings a true photo enthusiast is normally concerned about, such as exposure compensation, ISO, aperture, shutter speed and optical zoom. The LCD screen produces images that are, bright, crisp and clear, even in the bright light of mid day. I have yet to encountered difficulty seeing the image on the screen - and I have not had to adjust the screen brightness setting to maximum. In spite of its excellent LCD scr ... een, I wish it had an optical view finder - but only because i am used to composing shots that way. But truth be told, using the LCD screen has some advantages over an optical finder. The biggest drawback is in the camera's long shutter delay. Anyone used to a fast shutter on a DSLR - especially for taking action shots or trying to capture those special fleeting expressions on the face of children - will sorely miss the instantaneous response of an SLR. So while I love the PowerShot S95, it will never replace my Nikon D300 or D700. The other minor drawback is a mediocre battery life. A spare battery is a must for anyone who is used to taking multiple images of the same, or nearly the same, object or scene. If you refrain from using the video feature, battery life is OK - but still not great. But the video is a nice feature, so why would you want to avoid using it because of concern about the battery life? Over all, this is an excellent pocket camera. I tend to take it everywhere. And for those who are wondering how it compares to the new camera in iPhone 4, the PowerShot S95 is far superior. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: A great prosumer point and shoot plus
Item.Review: My wife and I have been using this camera for about a month now. We got it to replace a Canon Digital Elph, and (though the jump in price makes it obvious) it truly is a totally different category of camera. Colors are crisp and true; the images are sharp. Pictures are surprisingly good under low light too (not excellent, but good--this is a point and shoot, after all). Other features we like are the control rings around the zoom lens and around the control button on the back. The former offers more fine-tune control of zooming. The camera also offers HDR for pics under non-ideal lighting (e.g. sunset). HD video recording is also very nice. The only minor complaints we have about this camera are the standard ones: it is easy to place your finger over the pop-up flash, and it is not the ... fastest camera between pics. But my understanding is that for true rapid shooting, you really need to step up to a more expensive DSLR or similar camera. Oh--the battery life. It really is short. You'll definitely want to get a second back-up battery. You won't make it through a day of shooting without one. It would be nice if it had GPS, but it doesn't. But those complaints are relatively minor. If you want a powerful camera that takes great pictures and the form factor of a point-and-shoot that you can put in your shirt-pocket, Canon's S95 is a great choice. Highly recommended. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: SUPERB! more portable and affordable than competitors: (GF-1, LX5, G11 etc.) Very crisp images. Good low-light settings. Nice control with front and rear wheels, customizable settings. Easy to use for novice, and great advanced features. Battery life has been impressive, full day of shooting stills and video is no problem. Good macro focus. Clear and sharp, faithful JPG color rendering, best I've seen in a camera this size. Only gripes so far is 1. Digital zoom works while video is being recorded, but optical zoom and focus is locked on the setting that it started on. Full optical zoom can be utilized for video, but has to be set at beginning of recording. focus can't be changed while recording. 2. Has a hard time focusing unless an object is available to focus on (ie focus must f ... irst be set on a cloud in the sky, or horizon. Perhaps this can be changed with another focus setting. Very impressed with the first 500 images. Only a week old, but I'm very happy with the cell-phoneesque size and ease of use, can hand it to any amateur and they will find it easy to use. Great quality for a camera of its size. Solid construction. I will probably buy one of the underwater housings for it. You should BUY IT! see for yourself: [@] expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: does the job & excellent for underwater!
Item.Review: I own a Canon Rebel xti, which is not too heavy to travel with but, I don't have money for an SLR waterproof case ($1000 is too much for a student!). I've been watching for a good P&S with a not expensive compatible case and S90 was my top choice. However, I was hesitating because of the lack of HD video and I waited until the upgraded version s95 (yay!) appeared. The s95 and WP-DC38 did a great job in my first ocean dive trip. HD video is not perfect but I guess you're not supposed to expect something crystal clear from a small camera like this. Overall exceeded my expectation! About the camera itself, there are plenty of reviews online so I'm not going to say much. It does the job as described. Low light is very good, the color balance is always a little bit off compared with my xti ... . Love the ring function, much better than pushing lots of buttons... I'm still not used all the functions and there's still lots of potentials to increase image qualities by knowing the tricks of camera settings. By the way, a fully charged battery survived 3 dives (about 40min/dive), about 120 pictures and 15min HD video. With a spare battery should be enough. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Better than the sum of it's parts.
Item.Review:
Pros: Small, fast, great in low light, really smart camera
Cons: Needs an aftermarket grip to make it one-hand shootable.
This is an amazing camera and I'm very happy. I put a small grip on it to make it more like the G12 and it's in my pocket every day now as I move around on my daily jaunts.
I take it to parties and use it at street fairs. Kids and grownups, it's in my pocket and I use it. I take it with me every day I leave the house.
I started with a G12. I saw an artist that had huge blow ups from the G10. He recommended the new G12 to me. The I got the G12 but it was heavy and bulkier than I really wanted to carry. I've had big cameras; the sit at home. So I love the portability of this camera. The pictures are almost identical to the G12 and so is the sho ... oting experience. There are only a few times I miss the G12; when I have a crowd in front of me and I need the articulating view finder for example; that that is rare. It really doesn't come up that often.
I find as I get to know the S95, it fits my needs, I can compensate for it's lack of features in leiu of carrying it with me at all times. This day and age, we all have a civic duty to capture current events and I'm ready at all times. I also love to take pictures of people, and plants and animals that come my way. And the shots of my kids have really improved.
I have set mine up to be silent, to take multiple pictures as I hold down the shutter button and to not show me pictures at all as they are taken. This really speeds up how fast the camera can resume and take the next shot and nobody even knows I'm shooting; I just hold down the button with the camera on, as I hold it against my body, not even framing and I get great shots as I walk or stop to take in the scene. Very artistic and timely, I like shots that would usually never accept being photographed or framed with any delay at all.
As far as memory, don't spend a lot of money on a fast memory cart. Any level 10 card will do, this camera is not that fast to need a supper fast hi-end memory card. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Pros: Fast/accurate auto-focus, Good Image Quality, Large Clear LCD, Small / Compact ... Cons: Poor placement of flash, Short Battery Life I bought this camera for vacation pictures with my family. I am a professional videographer and photographer and was tired of dragging my heavy professional stuff with me on family trips. As a result I missed many shots. This camera you can tuck in your pocket but still has many features that I like. It can be completely automatic or you can override all the features and make it manual. I can hand this camera to my wife who has no professional photography experience and get some nice shots. It is capable of shooting in RAW which really adds to the clarity and ones ability to crop/color correct, etc without a loss in quality. It does mean the files get l ... arge. So buy a big card, its worth it. It has the ability to be completely manual. Which I like since we all know sometimes automatic settings don' always yield the best results. I can even do predictable flash daylight fill shots. I was surprised at the quality of the video too. I mean really surprised. It shoots in 1280x720 or 640x480 format which looks incredible. So now I do not have to pack the video camera either. It does have a few faults. The flash is placed in such a spot that while holding the camera, it tends to keep the flash from popping up when needed. The zoom is also very limited in it's range. However, it is perfect focal length overall though for family candids. Be sure to keep the battery charged at the end of the day. It can burn through power pretty fast. I bought a second battery just to be safe. Overall I am very pleased with this camera. No point and shoot camera can do it all but this one comes very close. Hope this review helps you in making the right choice! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Has all the features of a SLR camera. Portable - Perfect to fit in my jeans pocket. Sturdy - Metal frame. Perfect weight. Feels good. Great screen size, with GREAT colors and definition. Pics look awesome on the screen. Quick On and Off for quick moments. Shock resistant
Cons: Pictures do not look the same once you download them to your PC. Use a software to add more color/contrast and that's it! Flash pops-up exactly where you have your finger to hold the camera. Can't control flash (On-Off) in "auto" mode.
Over all it is an EXCELLENT camera. We love it!

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Just got this camera a week ago so I don't know everything about it yet. But the color is better than the Canon Powershot S45 or the A720 IS. The display is beautiful and bright, and despite the camera having lots of features, the controls are easy to use and well organized. Smile mode and wink mode - two goofy features I did not even know about and may rarely use - make everyone laugh. So maybe I will use them after all. Problems: I keep accidentally changing the exposure level by inadvertently twirling the control wheel in the back. A little attention to the display allows me to notice and correct that, and I think I should be attending to the exposure anyway. Another troublesome thing for me is that this camera is SMALL, a little heavy for its size and it doesn't have any grips ... to hang on to. However, the surface finish is textured and I haven't dropped it while shooting so I guess it's okay. Be sure to use the wrist strap! I have an older Canon Powershot A720 IS that is a dog and refuses to accept any batteries. Nothing is good enough for it. I hope this new PS95 - which uses NB-6L batteries - will presumably get along with its batteries like my PS S45 does. After one week I can't say. The pictures are great! And I like having quick access to the ISO settings! And it easily makes HDR images! This camera does exactly what I want - it gives me control over my images, but it fits in my pocket so I can carry it anywhere. Yay! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Canon's S95 is a great digital camera (own 2 old Canons S500 & G6). S95 has wonderful optics, sharp focus, superb colors and easy to navigate buttons/menus. Battery power could be better, however I carry an extra battery, no big deal. Very, very happy with purchase from wonderful B & H Photo NYC. Bought all Canon digital cameras from them [...]

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Literally everything is flawless.
Cons: It looks expensive, so I'm afraid of it getting stolen.
This camera is amazing, I rarely use my DSLR anymore since I bought it. Let me sum up the advantages:
1. Incredibly build quality, very solid, made of metal. 2. Perfect photos every time, never messes up exposure or gets the colors wrong. 3. Shoots in RAW, so you have a lot of control. 4. Very easy to change manual settings. Control ring is awesome. 5. Depth of field is much better than any other point and shoot I have used. Makes photos very interesting and they look professional. 6. Small size is great, you can bring it everywhere because it actually fits in your pocket. 7. It's FAST, it can shoot photos rapidly and there is no delay when you press ... the shutter to when it snaps the picture. 8. The detail is incredible even in auto mode, I edited over a dozen photos in Lightroom 3 before I realized they were all JPEG and not RAW.
Seriously don't be put off by the price, it's worth every penny. It's one of those purchases where I am 100% satisfied and would much rather have the camera than the money I spent. In fact, I refuse to buy a cheap camera again. I would rather not have a camera than use anything less than this one. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Oversisded CMOS sensor, Lens speed, image quality, battery life, low light results, easy settings with lens ring..
Cons: Would like to see panoramic sweep and burst shot capability.
I am a marketing consultant for many industries but a large part of my focus is in the medical community where web sites, printed materials, articles, etc. are a must. This means on the spot shots of exam rooms, staff doing things, waiting room or procedure room shots on the fly. I have many cameras as I used to be a full time pro some years ago. Nothing has ever come close to the performance, quality and clarity of the images that come out ot the S95. For more demanding work I also have a Canon 50D, Canon G-10, Sony SDSC-HX5 and a closet full of film cameras with over 30 lenses. (I stil use ... film in some special instances) but the one camera I carry with me at all times is the S95.
Low light situations tranform into soft glowing crystal clear images without flash. Easy to change manual settings on the fly with the lens ring make using this camera a snap. Best of all the battery offers great life use on a fully charged status and the SD cards for memory are a blessing. While my Sony can do some trick stuff I wish this Canon could do (ie: stitched images on the fly, plus panoraic sweeps and burst shots at many frames per second) I still cannot get the quality images this Canon presents. This means a lot less post edit time at my computer.
If you're looking for a small easy to carry nearly pro pocket camera the S95 is your choice. The FAST 2.0 lens was a dream just a year ago and now they're slowly becomming a bit of a standard for premium pocket cameras, but nobody quite measures up to the quality of the Canon lens and I've tested them all. WIth an oversized CMOS sensor even a pro like me will be impressed with the performance. I love it when a camera company sits down and figures out how to make the best camera they can for a reasonable price instead of the lowest priced camera with reasonable performance.
Best $400 you'll ever spend .... if you can find one. wr expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Being a DSLR user I was looking for P&S that would let me decide the settings in the camera to get the desired exposure and look. This camera does just that. With a large sensor in a small ( about the size of a deck of cards ) body, There is a lot of imaging capturing power in this pocket size camera. And when the wife wants to use it she just puts it into auto and can still captures impressive shots. Shooting at ISO 1600 with no flash is a big advantage with this camera and when using RAW it only gets better. Noise is very well controlled with the S95 and I have no problem capturing a clean shot at ISO 1600. This is a great little camera with HD video available just to add to this great package.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Style; Quality of images; Size
Cons: Pop up flash; Can be slow between pics
The reason why I came to Buydig was because their price for the camera was comparable to what I had wanted to pay from my initial research elsewhere. I had already done my research on the Canon S95 and knew this was the camera I wanted. So a word of advice: do your research before you buy.
The S95 could probably be considered the amateur's SLR. I'm not a professional photographer, and admittedly I'm not sure I can use this camera quite to its full potential. My last camera was a DSLR that my father gave me as a gift, so I have some experience with higher end cameras. Though I liked the DSLR, it is just too unwieldy.
The first thing you might notice about the camera is its size and ... build. It's got a slightly textured surface, weighs little and feels sturdy. The main dial on top is firm and won't be shifted accidentally (like how my other camera's dial was). Buttons are raised on the back of the camera for ease of use, while the ones on top are flush with the body, except for the shutter. All are immediately responsive and feel good. The only qualm people might have is that the pop-up flash might encroach on finger real estate. My fingers are slender, so there's enough space behind the pop-up flash for me, but others might find it a little awkward to place their fingers on the camera around the flash. If you think that might be the case, try before you buy.
This camera has a lot of settings, but what I like most is the ability to change shutter speed and aperture with just the slightest turn of a dial. My old camera had me jumping through hoops to do just that. There are 9 settings on the top dial including: Auto, Potrait, Custom, Manual, Program, Aperture Priority, Shutter Priority, Low Light and Standard (for videos). There is one setting ring on the front of the camera surrounding the telescoping lens, and another surrounding the multi-function button to the right of the LCD. Depending on the program, these rings do different things, including changing aperture and shutter speed.
I haven't had a chance to explore all of the features of the camera, including Wink Self-Timer, Smile Detection, Face Detection, Color Swap, Color Accent or HDR (which more serious photographers might want to look into), but there seems to be enough here to satisfy everyone.
Besides the features and appearance, performance is what we really care about. People have mentioned the slight amount of time between shots as being longer than they expected and/or desired. If you're not patient but are thinking of getting this camera, you might want to test this out at a local store before you commit. It doesn't bother me, but it might bother some. I'd say there's a 2 second delay between pictures, not including whatever you have set as image review time. The only other thing that I've heard is that battery life is lacking. I can't attest to that because I've only shot a few pictures here and there and haven't tested the battery's full capability. Check that out before you buy if that's going to be an issue.
Pictures from this camera are very nice and crisp. I don't know how the colors compare, but they seem true enough to me. There are options for changing the quality of images, such as for using RAW Jpegs and such.
Overall, I'd say I'm very happy with this camera. I would definitely recommend this to someone looking for a high end camera, with a plethora of settings that they might find on a DSLR. Like I said at the beginning, it's the amateur's SLR. It has enough settings and high enough performance to probably become a professional photographer's backup when he/she doesn't want to take their SLR out. There's a lot here for almost any type of user, in a nice-looking tidy package, and in the end, you probably won't regret getting this camera. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Most of the performance of a DSLR.
Item.Review: I usually shoot RAW, aperture priority, spot focusing, auto white balance, ISO 200 outdoors, auto ISO indoors, evaluative exposure. I limit the ISO to 1250, which, combined with f2.0 or f2.8 takes great pictures, without flash, in most indoor settings. This combo gives fantastic results, every bit as good (at least up to 8 x 10 prints) as any DSLR I've had. It's stealthy, good for discrete shooting, It doesn't make people so self conscious. I don't feel so much like a camera nerd, (as our daughter has occasionally labelled me). I take the camera with me a lot more than I have taken a DSLR, usually in the front pocket of my jeans or slacks. No camera case or neck strap needed. I find the front control ring too hard to turn, and the back control ring too easy to turn. Like everyone else, I ... occasionally get my finger rudely pushed away by the rising flash. After exhaustive research I've found the best way to avoid this is to not put my finger on top of the flash when I activate it (the flash that is). I really like this camera. Bill expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I'm usually a DSLR shooter (7D). But, I have carried around a Canon G9 in a backpack for a couple of years, assuming I would use it for day-to-day photographic opportunities. But, of its size, it was in a soft case that was in a back pack all the time. So, I was looking to replace it with a more pocketable alternative. I debated for months between the S95 and Panny LX5. I love the 24mm lens on the LX5, but I ultimately went for the S95 because I knew with it's small size, I could always have it in a coat pocket, ready to pull out on a second's notice. I have not been disappointed with my decision. It's already served it's purpose as a ready-at-all-times camera. Probably my biggest surprise with the camera is it's high-ISO image quality. I am amazed at how salvageable ISO 1600 and ... 3200 images are with Lightroom noise reduction. I feel like this camera delivers the same level of noise as my first Digital Rebel XT, although without the same dynamic range and color quality. My only complaints are lack of control over AF point location and lack of manual control in movie mode. If you're an experienced photographer, looking fora good camera to take everyone, you can't go wrong with the S95. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Excellent P & S for just about anything!
Item.Review: I normally shoot Nikon DSLR. Learned photography on a Nikon FE and never looked back. I have been dreaming of a decent camera that fits in my pocket but allows me full exposure control when I need it. The Canon S95 is that camera. Fits in your pocket yet has all the manual features you would expect from a larger camera. The front control ring is too cool. The f2 aperture doesn't hurt too. Though I do miss having a viewfinder, the screen is gorgeous and shows a preview of the exposure even before you shoot. The fact that the controls are so simple made this an even better deal for me. I took it on a scenery shoot last week and ended up using it as much as my Nikon D200. The auto features do spoil me a little???I end up not having to worry much about setting it manually, as it t ... akes very good photos in automatic mode. I tried the HDR feature???useless of course without a tripod. It's quite simple to set it to HDR and well, you just point and shoot and it does the rest. Video at 720p is nice, and audio is better than my FLIP. Not too happy about the flash, but hey it is a Point and Shoot, isn't it. Besides, I rarely get to use the flash. Very happy with this camera, get it, you will be too :) expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: A serious P&S for serious users!
Item.Review: If you are a photographer and need a P&S around, this is the one. Great image quality (considering its size), fast f/2.0-4.9 lens,usable ISO range of 80-800 and manual controls with a ring around the lens to control any setting like ISO, exposure, aperture and shutter speed. I got good results shooting in extreme low light conditions and the video quality in 720P is outstanding for this little camera. The battery life is not bad but I recommend buying an extra to be sure. It's pricey but worth every penny. Only two point disappointed me: no auto focus and no zoom during video recording. You need to set the focus and zoom prior to record. If you need a pocket size camera with a huge range of features and settings, manual controls and excellent image/video quality don't look elsewher ... e, buy it. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: As an avid photographer and semi-professional, I've yearned for a point and shoot camera that I could easily fit into my pocket but also give me the features I expect cameras to have in today's media-crazed society, i.e. HD video and a big sensor for top notch photographs. The Canon S95 delivers on both. THe design is nearly flawless. The picture quality is fantastic and the HD video is nearly as good as some of the high end video cameras I've used as of late. The various modes give you the option to shoot wide angles, HDR, landscape, portrait, scenes, etc. The manual zone gives is photographers the chance to manually dictate the type of shot we want. This camera is great in low light and the zoom function, couple with the manual focal selection ensures that you'll always be able to c ... apture the shot you want. For such a small package, the Canon S95 performs as a high end DSLR at a fraction of the cost. I'd recommend this camera to not only professionals, but also regular camera fanatics who are looking to snap pictures to their hearts content. Go and get yours today! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Ease of use, Picture quality
Cons: Price...but it is worth it.
I purchased this camera to replace my Canon S90 which I left in a hot car and ruined. I didn't see how the images could be any better with the S95 but they are. I am a retired professional photographer and carry it everywhere I go. You wont know it is in your pocket. Out of curiosity I took identical photos with my Nikon 7000 DSLR and the S95 and compared them. Even at extreme enlargements there is no difference in the images. The Nikon cost over one thousand dollars without a lens. I love the Canon and am considering purchasing another one to put away in case this one ever goes bad. Images are crystal clear, perfect color, great low light (I seldom need to use the flash) and easy to use. I have used a ... lmost all other brands at one time or another and Canon beats them all for my needs. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I'm a Nikon shooter when it comes to pro-level cameras, but I have to give Canon a big pat on the back for its point-and-shoots. This is the third one I've owned and they just keep getting better. Started with an A550 in 2005 and bought my lady friend an SD1300 that's fun to use (but since it's pink, I try to leave it for her. Guess I'm not all that secure with that kind of thing, huh?) I read many reviews and was leaning toward the G12, but liked the size of the S95 better. The reviews seemed better than the newer S100, too. I've used it for several weeks now and while the ergonomics are still a little cumbersome, I'm getting more familiar with where the buttons and features are. Only real problem is continually putting my left forefinger on top of the pop-up flash, but since I rar ... ely use flash, it's not that big of a deal. I'll learn! And speaking of flash, having two stops plus and minus worth of flash exposure is thrilling! I shoot the camera in program mode most of the time to control the flash so I like the ability to assign certain functions to the buttons or the ring at the base of the lens -- that makes accessing certain often-used features more quickly when needed. I set white balance and particularly custom WB often, and it's a breeze. Plus seeing the changes on the LCD are most helpful. I really like how this camera feels and works and am glad I bought it! Just wish it had a real viewfinder. Yes, kids, we geezers need viewfinders! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I have been shooting with DSLRs for about 3 years now. Starting out with a Canon T2i and then to a Canon 5D and now to a Canon 5D MK II, but sometimes I just want a small point in shoot that I can carry around in my pocket. The Canon S95, does just that. I have an iPhone but this thing blows it away, obviously. First off, the features. It shoots HD video along with high quality images. If you set it to full manual you have access to white balance, iso, aperture, shutter, and many other settings. There are lots of in camera options to give you some simple photoshop effects. The ISO bumping could be great so you can take shots without flash. I love this point and shoot and it's nice to have something that is not huge but still provides great images!

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Very pleased with the picture and product quality. Minimal need for touching up photos in general and red-eyes in particular. Flash vs lens positioning is such that I have not seen any red-eyes yet. The S95 can be set to full automatic and used as a simple point and shoot by the most inexperienced users in the family while allowing more experienced users the control they need via many of the settings found in DSLRs. The control ring and custom settings mode are convenient features that increase useability. One weakness is the video function which is of limited use due to the lack of continuous focus/zooming while filming. All-in-all, the S95 captures great images and is a completely viable alternative to lugging the DSLR kit when size and portability matter.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: No better time to get an S95
Item.Review: Like everyone else looking at this class of camera, I was looking for optimum image quality in a small form factor, for occasions (especially those occasions that tend to be indoors, and often under low light conditions...like weddings, social gatherings, etc.) when bringing my dSLR (a 40D) along was simply not practical. Previously, I was often getting by at such times with my G9 and a small flash, but even that was sometimes too big of a kit to bring along-- it required a separate bag, and was large enough to be noticeable. Plus, its image quality (with flash, indoors) is great, but it is rather slow in terms of focusing and shutter lag. I also have a Panasonic ZS6, which is a GREAT compact (similar to ZS5 and ZS7) with a great zoom range for full daylight, but it struggles indoors. So ... when prices on the S95 fell to truly low levels following the release of the new S100, I finally decided one more camera wouldn't hurt, and bought one. All I can say now is, I wish I had bought this camera even earlier, even at full intro. price, because I can think of a number of events over the past year where I just skipped bringing a camera altogether, where the S95 would have been absolutely ideal. It's unobtrusive, it's quick ENOUGH for most spontaneous shots, and it's shockingly good in low light (there is some noise in the shadows, if you look for it intently, but very little detail smearing even in JPEGs), while still retaining great color accuracy and saturation. The auto white balance does a great job on this camera. The control ring on the front makes it immensely flexible and quick to change settings. (Although the menu system is also easy and intuitive.) And to top it off, I can slip it in my purse (or, for the non-purse-carrying guys or gals, it will slide subtly into a pants or jacket pocket with no problem), so that it's there if needed/wanted, but out of the way otherwise. Now I get what all the pocketability fuss is about. I have quickly adapted to holding this tiny camera so that my finger doesn't interfere with the rising flash on the top left. The rear control ring and buttons might be a challenge for people with large fingers, but if you can send a text on a cellphone you can definitely learn to handle the S95. I have a Richard Franiec grip on my G9 and feel it is absolutely a necessary accessory on that camera, but the slightly rough finish on the S95 really does seem to be sufficient to allow a good grip, and I think it looks classy and svelte as-is. (The grip looks good, though, and might be a good idea if you plan to use this camera a lot on vacation and might be carrying it in your hand at-the-ready for long periods of time, to reduce the fatigue caused by squeezing/pinching a flat camera). At current prices, if you can afford to even be shopping on this website, the S95 is an eminently sensible purchase, and one you ought to make no matter what other serious camera(s) you may already own. Why do I say that? Because it excels at being a companion you can take along with you virtually all the time, that won't weigh you down or let you down. You will say wow quite often when you look at the images you can capture with it. You will miss fewer moments during the upcoming holiday seasons with your friends and family, because a) you can always have an easy-to-operate camera with pretty sensational image quality with you, and b) that same camera won't require futzing around with changing lenses, waiting for your big shoe-mounted flash to recycle, and won't give you those blurred shots you sometimes get because the depth of field on your (heavy and cumbersome) f/1.4 low light lens was too narrow and you or it missed focus. When you share pictures you've made with the S95 with others, they will also often say wow, and also thank you. I think the S in the Canon S-series should stand for social, because this (and its line-mates, the S90 and S100) is really the perfect social camera. It gets the shot, and the shot it gets is really, really good. Buy it and enjoy it. Oh, and yes the battery... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: components, feel, image quality, price, speed, manual controls
Cons: zoom
I love Canons, particularly this camera. I have purchased two (one for a friend) There's a lot said about this model, and even after all 'the hype', I feel happy every time I boot the thing up. What I've noticed that I didn't gather from reviews, is that with the S95 I am taking less and less shots in "auto-mode". The manual dials are intuitive enough that it is worth my while to get the shot right by my own eyes. The only thing that seems to be lacking in this camera is some more serious optical focus. But I purchased this camera specifically for a trip up a coastal highway and for indoor (party) pictures. The video and audio quality - also a big plus! And the last unexpected surprise wa ... s how easy it was to find great values on class 10 SDHC cards and so called "off-brand" batteries, that work just as good as the canon flavor. Love this camera, enjoy! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I bought this camera to help me teach a digital photo class. I usually use a slr, but most of my students use a point and shoot. Because it does not have a view finder, it is hard for me to focus on what I want. The flash also is located where you would hold the camera. But, the pictures are very good and it has lots of interesting features to play around with. It also has video and that makes the camera fun. The camera is small and good for taking pictures on the go.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I bought this camera because it has many of the same features as an SLR, but it was compact. This is my second Canon Powershot. My older one is 6 years old and still going strong. I just wanted something more up to date. I am impressed with its picture quality, especially in low light and at a distance, using the zoom. The images are clear and not grainy. I've only had the camera for about 2 months, so I haven't had a chance to explore all the features. I like the display in the back. it has a helpful reference which explains the feature. Video quality is very good, but can be shaky. I think it could be improved if you had a tripod. I miss not having a view finder, but am getting used it it. With the camera, you can control the exposure length and aperture. The only thing that I ... am not crazy about is the pop-up flash. It's right where your finger sits to hold the camera. In low light it comes up automatically. I'm afraid it will break over time, or if the camera were to fall and land on it, it wouldn't survive the crash. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Good Image Stabilization; Large Clear LCD; Good Image Quality
Cons: Poor Flash; Short Battery Life
I'm still not comfortable with this camera after a few months of casual use. Granted I haven't taken as many pictures lately as I normally do. There just are some design/ergonomic issues that I haven't gotten used to. Depending on the situation I normally use a DSLR, or in the past an older Canon Digital Elph. I bought this camera as a higher quality replacement for that pocket camera.
A huge drawback for me is the flash. It pops up on the left top of the camera, exactly where I would normally put my left index finger. It sounds like a small issue, but I've always held a pocket camera that way, and it doesn't feel natural to hold it differently. I'm not sure why the ... y needed a retractable flash in the first place. What would be actually useful, is if they had a flash that could pivot vertically to bounce off of the ceiling. That would be worth the money.
Another design aspect I don't like is the body finish. Its sort of a matte or finely textured finish that is more grippy or friction inducing than other pocket digitals. With pocket cameras, you want to be able to quickly pull them out of your pocket & slide them back in with ease. This particular camera doesn't do that for me. It takes more effort, which lessens the overall enjoyment for me. Maybe I'm just spoiled. Maybe I need to stop wearing skinny pants.
It does have great image quality & a fantastic LCD. I wouldn't recommend this camera though. The great lens & image quality don't make up for the ease of use issue. To me it's not worth the extra $200+ for the quality. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Photo quality, Size, Options
Cons: Price may be too high for some
If you are looking for a point and shoot that you can easily carry with you, but want one that takes great pics, this is the camera for you. This camera takes amazing pictures and has both Auto and Manual options for beginners and pros alike. This camera packs a lot into a small package. Don't be fooled by the 10 megapixel label. This camera has a LARGE sensor relative to other point and shoot cameras. The sensor does more in picture quality than the megapixel number does. The larger sensor also helps it perform better in low light settings. Doing research, I read that when someone who normally uses a DSLR camera wants a smaller camera to stick in their pocket, the S95 is the camera they use. Don't be sca ... red by the price-It's well worth it! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Opinion has changed after using for a mo
Item.Review: I use this when I am on the go camping or other where I cannot carry my backpack.I love the size.I do not love the results I get. I had hopped my wife could get good results on auto but nope! Even in auto and decent light she would get blury photos.My initial feelings for this camera were very high as it had so many features similar as my SLR and I initially reviewed it quite high at B&H. However as I have used it for over a month now my 5 or 4 star rating is more like a 2. Why such a drastic drop? First the rating dropped from a 3 to a 2 because I feel more ripped off by the [$] cost as I see the problems this expensive camera has and they really are inexcusable. Some may say they are caused bue user error. Simply not the case.Here is a short laundry list of the problems I have ran ... on to that I did not see at first.1. When videoing the video will have some ghosting image go across the screen ??? the camera is not hot not the environment hot either. 2. The camera will randomly insert a date stamp as you take pictures. With the same settings without any changes to the settings whatsoever one picture will have a DS and the very next will not. I hate DS and do not prefer to remove them. IF you like DS it is still a bad thing because it apparently will turn off on you too maybe.3. Rapid shoot is atrociously slow ??? for [$] you should get at least 3/second even in RAW format4. I specifically have the camera set up for spot focus in the center of the camera and it will take blurry photos and when it does this it messes up the exposure generally also.5. The flash is on the most obnoxious place ever and when others have used the camera that is the first thing they say about the camera.6. The stereo microphones are in very bad places at the bottom of the camera and since the camera is so small (good thing though) you can't help but cover them with a finger or two as you hold it. By far if video recording use a pod of some kind. I still like the camera but if I had it to do over again I would go with a different camera. It is absolutely not worth[$] expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: I call it my "SLR on the Go!"
Item.Review:
Pros: Durable, Size, Image Quality, Image stabilization, Low Light Setting, SLR type setting capability
Cons: Flash location
I LOVE this camera. I typically shoot with a Canon 40D but sometimes you just can't haul that thing around. This camera gives me all the great features but weighs a fraction of the SLR. I never leave home without it! It's been around the world and I have amazing pictures to prove it. The night shots are incredible with the lowlight settings, and the image stabilization helps on those fast train rides in Europe. My only complaint so far is the flash location. I had to find a new way to hold the camera so I didn't block the flash from popping up. But worth it for the results! If the pictures don't sell this camera the quality should! My husband left ... my camera outside and I found it three rainy days later. Not a drop of condensate in the lens or screen! I've dropped it, smashed it into my luggage, and left it in the rain for three days, that's a pretty serious test to pass with flying colors! Highly recommended to anyone serious about their picture taking. And a great tool to learn more about camera settings and functions. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: size and weight
Cons: Inconsistent color reproduction
Having read the hype I purchased this camera and it was the worst camera I have ever owned. I took a series of pictures within seconds of the same stationary object with the same settings, from the same position and same lighting. The reason I repeated the pictures is that each one had a different hue. Some had a pinkish hue, some with yellow, some blue grey. The pictures might be rectified on the computer, however one does not expect to have such inconsistency in color with a camera that costs $400. At that price range I would expect a camera to at least have consistant colors.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Nice Feature Set, Small, Great Screen, Shoots RAW
Cons: Died after 2 weeks, colors seem a little flat.
I am a HUGE Canon fan so this review is a little hard to write. I bought this camera based on various reviews and its feature set. I especially like the fact that it shoots RAW. This was to be used as my carry with me camera since it is very small relative to my G11.
I had this for a little over 2 weeks and took a total of 12 pictures with it then this past weekend I went to take some pictures while out on a scenic ride and low and behold I was shocked when I got a "Lens Error" when I turned it on. I tried several times and got the same thing. I removed the battery and waited a while then tried again with the same error.
This camera was in a Lowepro prote ... ctive case from the second it came out of the box and it was never dropped or even bumped.
I brought it back to BB and they tried to tell me that it was outside of their 14 day return policy then said they would do me a favor and swap it out for me otherwise I would be looking at a restocking fee. I told them I am a Premier Silver Member and he said oh then you have 45 days and there isn't any restocking fee.
I considered getting another one but didn't want to take a chance having this happening again when I needed it to work. I looked at other options but decided to hold off for now.
Of the photos I did get / take with it I was impressed with the quality but the colors weren't very saturated and this was both in JPEG and RAW. The auto focus was very fast and accurate and there is very little shutter-lag.
Maybe I just got a lemon? I don't know but for something that I am not going to use every day I need to know it is going to work when I want it to so I decided to do a little more research. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: S95 - Canon Black PowerShot 10 Megapixels Digital Camera review
Item.Review:
Pros: Excellent for av user,Fast/accurate auto-focus,Small / Compact,Good in Low Light,Large Clear LCD,Good Image Stabilization,Good Image Quality,Nice Body Color,Easy To Use
Use on world wide travel- Indoors & out. Just received it . Have another Canon Auto Focus which is very good.
Tested most of the features. Everyone worked very well. Photos were excellent! Indoor auto focus low light pics. were great. There is little not to like about this camera. Ease of use, light weight, compact. quality build.
