Flash location requires getting use to. Battery life after extensive testing was somewhat limited. Would suggest purchasing a second one if you shoot large amounts in a single session.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: This is an easy to use compact camera It has improved image stabilizer comes in handy, so you can take photo with continuous shooting even on the bus. Auto-focus and colour output are good enough for casual use. I have no problem with short shutter lag on this one. The only thing needs to be concerned about this camera is the battery life Recommend purchase a backup battery. For pocketable camera, this is currently the best one to choose (size-wise)

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Speed, picture quality, size.
Cons: Price is high for a point and shoot--but fair based on the quality
I bought my wife a Lumix ZS1 last year to replace a Canon S80 (a predecessor of this camera) that she had accidentally crushed after 5 great years. She was quite disappointed. The Lumix is a fast camera, one of the faster point-and-shoots on the market, just not fast enough to capture quick shots of the kids, the little ones especially because they won't sit still. This camera's got speed to kill. Focuses and shoots faster than my Nikon D70 and my Nikon D200 under real-life situations (especially the more challenging ones with low-contrast backgrounds). It's good enough to leave the DSLR at home and not worry about missing out on great picture quality or speed--and it' ... s extremely pocketable. Zoom range is phenomenal, low light performance far exceeds both my DSLRs, and it even takes great macro shots. Colors are rich and natural (makes the Lumix photos look rather faded, actually). I highly recommend this camera. Oh, yeah, and my wife loves it too--no more complaints. My only complaint is that I wish I had two of these--now I'm stuck with the Lumix, expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Great Point and Shoot for Pro's
Item.Review:
Pros: Picture Quality, nice features
Cons: Battery life with video (but expected)
I'm a photographer and love taking pictures but I don't always carry a DSLR with me at all time. I bought a Canon G9 a while back for more portability but it was still pretty big. Other point and shoots just didn't have the quality i was looking for but I bought this because it was a step below the G12 and but was much small. Reviews we very good so i bought it and was surprised at the picture quality. I was fishing in hawaii and took it with me and it took very vivid pictures. I like playing around with the features but there aren't many new functions that i haven't seen on other canon point and shoots. The ring takes a bit to get use to but is kind of nice if you can get the hang of it. Also I ... bought a 8GB SDHC Class 10 card and it allows me to record video without any issues. I would say the only issue i had was battery life with recording video but i expected that. I'll probably get a second battery so if i'm doing a lot of video i'll have a back-up. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: So this little guy has been a great photo buddy. I own a DSLR and when I pull it out among friends they all run and hide, but with this little camera it's so small and portable that they don't mind posing for a few shots. Another great advantage is the size of this device! It's so small and compact that I can take it anywhere I go (as cliche as that may sound, I swear to you it's true). The disadvantage though to this product is obviously the price (but for me, to each his own I guess). You'd figure they throw in extra items in the box but they don't even include the full camera manual. You'd have to either download directly from the Canon site or another site that offers that choice. Also there's a way you can do manual focus on this camera but to be honest I personally don't think it ... really helps since it's all on the LCD unless it's real obvious (nothing beats a viewfinder). Concluding, this camera is great. Stick to Auto focusing (there's also this smart focus option) and you'll get great photos with or without the flash. Small, compact, and perfect for any occasion. The design is sleek and classy. I'd recommend it tl;dr - Small, sleek point-and-shoot camera that produces great quality. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Takes beautiful pictures, stepped up the video to HD from the SD90, nice feel to the camera
Cons: I can't lie, b/c of the price I was hesitant to buy it. But I'm glad I did.
Imma keep this review simple and to the point. Awesome picture quality, very nice build. Doesn't feel to small where you may drop it often, yet its not bulky.
Has some nice features for the professionals out there as well as a good enough Auto mode for beginners.
Took some pictures of random things since I've gotten it (including Mardi Gras parades here in New Orleans) and I've posted them. Even though Best Buy crops them down so much you can't really enjoy the quality of these photos.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I wanted a camera that I could carry in my purse or backpack ready to use whenever needed. I have a Canon 40D but that is just too heavy to lug around. This works great. I thought at first maybe the s95 was a little overkill with the complexity of everything one can do with it. But I find I like the extra controls that mimic a dslr. I am an artist who likes to sketch and paint en plein air (outside). I always like to take a photo of the scene when I am painting or sketching. I also like to take photos of my work at it various stages; having a little camera like this is very convenient. As a teacher I am finding it great to use in the classroom. I teach art to adults. I use the camera to take photos of their work as it progresses. I can take photos of my demos and send it to them a ... fter class. The uses of this camera limitless to me. I even take it with me when I go for a walk around the neighborhood. One never knows when a digital moment will show itself. I have not used the HD movie mode yet so I can't comment on it. I agree with most everyone else the battery life is not good but it isn't a deal breaker for me. I just bought an extra battery. When I use my dslr I can in some circumstance take up to 800 photos in less than an hour. I don't see me doing anything like that with this camera. The book says you can get 200 photos from a charge. I think I did a little better than that. The s95 will never take the place of my Canon 40D but it has allowed me to make photography something I will do everyday now. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Best shirt-pocket size camera Canon S95
Item.Review: Canon S95 is the best shirt-pocket size camera as of February 2011, in terms of RAW image quality and all around ease of use plus manual controls. Nice new features like RAW files support, focus bracketing, and improved low light performance.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Great second camera for DSLR owners
Item.Review:
Pros: Picture quality and manual control features
Cons: Ergonomics as noted
The image quality is as good as I had heard. No super fine jpg compression so for anything serious I recommend shooting RAW or JPG/RAW. JPG files are small for a 10mp camera, about 2.5 mb. Quality is still great. Movie mode is very good for 24fps.....more than acceptable for casual clips. I would have liked to have seen at least 30fps.......but not a big deal. Ergonomics however were disappointing. First, the shutter button is set in to the left and the mode control wheel is where the shutter button should have been, the result is a tendency to push the control wheel to take a shot. It does take some getting used to but if you are going to hand the camera to someone to take a shot you better mak ... e sure they know where the shutter button is, otherwise it will blow the shot or take too much time. Second, the function wheel on the back of the camera moves way to easy without realizing it. On many occasions I have moved the wheel while holding the camera resulting in over or under exposing by 2/3 to 1 2/3. The fix here is to change the ring function to +/- which will change the exposure override to the front ring which is nice and tight and the ISO function to the back wheel, this way if you actually move it you are only changing ISO which is not as critical. My advice: CHECK THE SCREEN BEFORE YOU SHOOT TO MAKE SURE THE WHEEL HASN'T MOVED. Third, the pop up flash is a nice feature to reduce red-eye but it is located exactly where you hold the camera with your left hand. You have to move your hand when it pops up which is annoying. Incredible small size for the quality you get....if you can get passed the above issues, this is the one......if not, look at the Canon G12or the Lumix DMC-LX5 expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Robust performer in a small package!
Item.Review: I bought this camera to serve me on those occasions where the bulk of my DSLR just wouldn't be practical. I have not been disappointed. It has excelled for me in low light situations, and the video recordings are very good. I added a small grip and always carry a spare battery. In my judgement, it' s a lot of camera for the money.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: For indoor use the F2.0 lens is unbeatable.
Item.Review:
Pros: Low light capability, size, image quality and features
Cons: Battery life, limited zoom, not as clever panorama function as Sony
I was seeking to buy an enthusiast style camera that would allow my wife to pursue her interest in photography. She is a relative notice but has an appreciative eye. The menu system is great for a new learner and the manual and raw image capability provide room to grow. It is abour as small as you'd want a camera and still be able to manipulate controls, in fact, it's a good thing they have image stabilization as holding the camera still while pressing the shutter is a challenge, but one that doesn't affect image quality.
It has already taken some of the best technical pictures and renders some great dynamics in color tone. In the attac ... hed photo zoom in on the Santa and you see some really nice gradation in tones and enough resolution to pick up dust specks. The f2.0 narrow depth of field is also great to have. The second photo of Christmas ornaments used a feature that blends three exposures to enhance dynamic range and solves proper exposure from bright lights to ornaments in the tree's shadow. We compared it to the Panosonic Lumix ZS7, Nikon S8100, and Sony NEX 3. The Sony NEX 3 did edge it out with image quality. The Nikon videos were disappointing, The Canon and Sony were much more consistent in getting a good exposure. In the end the Canon was much more versatile and easy to keep in a pocketbook for the unplanned inspiration.The Pansonic could not compete in the indoor light that makes up a lot of family picture taking. If we ever travel I would buy a back up battery. Would love a teleconverter to up the optical zoom. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: After much research and reading of reviews I finally narrowed down my choices for a fast point and shoot street camera. I normally shoot with DSLRs (Canon 50D and Canon 30D) and in China where I live this always scares off people in a big way. I needed something with a good wide angle and that also could shoot pictures in low light very well. I previously was using a Canon G9 and the camera's controls were very user unfriendly and always confusing to use quickly. So I was a little cautious and hesistant about purchasing another Canon compact digital although I love all of the other Canon products. Now about the camera...........SIMPLY AMAZING is all I can say about this camera. If your looking for a fast ultimate street camera you could not make a better choice in choosing this camera. I ... am very very picky about this aspect of cameras and this camera has far exceeded all of my expectation in terms of speed of autofocus, very very short lag time between exposures. Although you can't compare this to a DSLR, it's plenty fast enough to take multiple pictures of any moving subject. Initially I found the camera a little difficult and awkward to use because it's so small and I was consequently (still am......) accidentally pressing some of the control buttons when holding the camera. One small annoyance is that I am constantly accidentally hitting the on and off flash button which is situated in the lower most right hand corner of the camera. But the more I use the camera the more I love it and the faster I am with it. It's of course a trade off with having such camera this small because of course all of the controls will be much smaller than a DSLR, BUT this camera sacrifices very little in terms of picture quality. The photos I have test photos I have taken thus far have been under very difficult situations I have had nothing short of outstanding results. Most of the time reader's or photo review sample photos never show the kind of photos I like to take such as people MOVING and in very low light WITHOUT flash. This camera is SHARP SHARP SHARP at the widest opening and at very slow hand held shutter speeds. As a photojournalist I know that anything less than 1/250 for moving pictures results in very marginally sharp photos. But I shot many pictures all the way down to 1/20th in very low light and the photos were all perfectly sharp............and most importantly these photos were taken of people not stationary subjects. I enlarged the photos in Photoshop and was blow away at the EDGE TO EDGE sharpness of all of my photos when shot at the widest aperture.I shot inside moving trains and in very cold weather conditions outside and the camera performed flawlessly. The one downside of the camera is the very short battery life although as I mentioned before I was shooting most of my early test photos in very cold (NorthEast China cold.......-15 centigrade) conditions and now that I have returned to warmer climate in Beijing (0 degree centigrade.......ha ha ha) I find the camera battery life obviously a lot better although still very short. No matter. I just bought a lot of spare batteries and it's a small trade off for all of the other amazing things this camera can do. I want to say that when I first saw this camera it was hard for me to believe that such a SMALL camera would be able to take such amazing quality photos. But after I read that this camera had the same sensor as its big brother Canon G12, this is what sold me on the camera. I am not big on the pop up flash and I have always have to make sure my hand is not covering the flash to prevent it from popping up accidentally when taking photos. It's a minor annoyance though and I found the quality of the flash to be very good at times and iffy at other times. Now about the control ring....Canon definitely got this one right when they decided to create this very wonderful feature. It was a little awkward at first to use having to push first the button, choose the mode and then do whatever adjustment you wanted to make with the control ring, but once... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Reviewer: Just like to take pics here and there...
Item.ReviewTitle: Good Mix of Ease and Power
Item.Review: I was looking for a small, powerful PS to augment my Nikon D70 (getting a little tired of hauling it around). I normally just take posed shots and scenery, so the speed of the D70 mostly isn't necessary. I would like more zoom, but i guess i can't have everything. I like the combination of easy PS features and control to manual set everything. As with most PS, the flash is weak. Love the size. Fits in the pocket easily. The battery life is short, but not horrible. Got an extra battery and that helps. The lag isn't bad and I don't miss too many shots. I'm used to using a viewfinder, but I'm getting used to not having it. Pros: -PS and Enthusiast features. -Small -Takes some good pics -Fairly fast. -Easy to use (if you don't get too caught up in the features). Cons: -Weak Fla ... sh -Zoom -Battery Life -No Viewfinder expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Compact size, great image quality, good ISO range.
Cons: Limited zoom
The Canon PowerShot S95 is a compact, feature rich camera in an impeccably finished package. Image quality from the 10 megapixel sensor is excellent and the anti-shake works very well. The 3-inch LCD display is bright and crisp and the camera has a usable ISO range of 80-800. Surrounding the lens is a control ring that can be set to adjust the ISO and focal length among other functions. For a DSLR owner, this is a great camera to have when a larger camera is not practical.
The zoom is somewhat limited, with a 28-105mm f/2.0 35mm equivalent range. And there's a little distortion at 28mm. Also, the mode dial requires more effort to turn than most.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: very good point&shoot camera. Shooting in low light [f2.0 lens], and in Raw are a plus. however, the raw file is not compatible with older photo editor software [unless i upgrade] other than the Canon photo editor software that came with the camera. The Canon photo editor software is OK. The 720p video is very good. I recommend having an extra battery though. Shooting in Raw or 720p vids depletes the battery rather quickly than jpeg shooting. I would have rated this camera 5 stars or 'excellent' if Canon upgraded to 1080p. Overall, i'm very satisfied with the camera. ...

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I've had numerous point and shoot digital cameras, and a half dozen DSLRs, so have a decently broad point of reference for the S95. My hope, like this camera's supposed target market, was for a very portable P&S with marginally better image quality and manual controls. In sum, it does deliver images with a wee bit less noise compared to other 10 mp P&S cameras. It DOESN'T improve at all on resolution. I found color rendition less than acceptable - with JPegs, reds and blues are oversaturated - even when the camera has been changed to neutral. The other big surprise was how the boxey and small size of the camera is really difficult to hold (I've got medium to large size male hands). Finally, i found the camera's shooting speeds (focus to shutter release, and shot to shot) to be ... slower than my previous canon SD880. So, for the price (I paid [$]), i thought this just wasn't worth it, so i returned it. I'm still on the search for that easily carried, more responsive point and shoot...am now considering the canon pwrsht 4000. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I got my wife a Fuji F10 a few years back that she loved and used until it finally just fell apart. We were going on a trip and decided to get her a new camera at [...], so after some looking around, we chose the Nikon Coolpix S3000. Big mistake. Disappointing build quality, incredible slow in every way, and the photos were terrible.We licked our wounds and decided to research a bit more and make sure we got the right camera. After reading reviews for days, the S95 started to emerge as the current favorite among trusted folks, so we decided to pony up the extra money and get it.I so wish we had just bought this camera in the first place. It's got a great, solid feel; it's fast on startup, focus, and between shots; but most of all, the photo quality is top notch. I'm a part-time profe ... ssional photographer, and I can honestly say that the photos this camera is capable of rival the quality I get from my 4 lbs of DSLR contraption I lug around everywhere.The lens is bright, fast and sharp. The LCD is huge. The optical zoom is adequate. Features like autofocus and image stabilization work quickly and as you would expect from a high-end camera. The components all seem to be top-notch.The video is very high quality and rivals DSLR video, but isn't fully baked yet -- no focus or zoom during shooting. It's too bad, because that could be a great feature.The S95's usability is really well thought out as well. In fully manual mode, the controls are intuitive and the options for tweaking your settings are plentiful and powerful. What's more important in my mind, being that this is a P&S, is that the automatic mode is very smart, very simple, and will take great images within a second or two of turning on the camera. They've hidden most of the manual features when auto is selected to avoid the whoa, what crazy configuration did you set up on this thing? questions. In Auto mode, the camera decides basically everything, and it's smart enough to make those decisions in a way that will produce great images really quickly.The only thing I don't like about this camera is the pop-up flash, but we've gotten used to it already and it certainly isn't a big deal.Bottom line, this camera may be twice the price, but I would gladly pay the extra money just to have had this camera on the trips we took with that cheesy junk of a Nikon. We couldn't be happier with the S95. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I'm a Graphic Design student. I've been using the product for small macro shots/video/other shots. The quality of the photos are amazing and all the random adjustment, make the possibilities endless. One thing I noticed after purchasing the camera was that there was no view finder. I know this was eliminated for a bigger LCD screen, but it takes the professional aspect out of the camera.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I'm an avid fan of B&H, as well canon products. 3 weeks ago I flew into town to watch my brother run the NYC Marathon. I deliberately did not bring my Canon 40d as I had planned to go to B&H to buy myself a good 'point and shoot' for traveling. [ I love my Canon 40d but it's not always the most practical thing to be lugging around with you. ] My brother has the Canon G12- which I played with for a day and absolutely loved it. My only issue with it is I wanted something you can stick in your pocket and travel light with. The G12 is just on this side of large. Is slighly smaller than the body of my 40d...but about 1/3 size larger than the S95. Which is where we begin our comments. I bought the Canon powershot s95 for it's 'pocket-ability', not to mention I was told that it does ever ... ything the G12 does, [with the exception the G12 has a view finder, a swivel screen, adoptable lens and a hotshoe for a real flash. Not to mention the S95 was about a $100 less.]. Further more the S95 with gun-metal body and super sharp screen, was to good to resist. It's a beautiful looking point & shoot camera. I took various shots around the city and then back home in panhandle of florida. I experimented with various lighting conditions; scene modes; subject matter; with flash on or off; with Iso settings; with program mode vs. auto mode. all in alI, took about 25 to 35 'experimental' shots. Guess what? 75% of my images were full of noise with super soft focus on my subjects! About every tenth shot I'd get a decent crisp shot. Which made me think I wasn't using the camera properly. So, I'd shoot some more.. alas, after further use and test shots, I feel that's simply not the case. i was extremely disappointed with it's results. Basically, if all you're going to print is nothing larger than a 5x7, and you just want something to capture the moment without worrying so much about how sharp the images are, then perhaps you'll be ok with the powershot s95. However, if you're a nut about sharp images [such as I seem to be...] you'll be disappointed in the Canon s95 powershot. If you have to play with settings so much to get the right scence on the right subject matter to get the right shot- then what's the point of getting a point and shoot? I might as well just bring my d40 out to play and deal with the weight and size issue. This morning I called B&H to get my RMA number. I plan to exhange it for the G12. I should have stuck to my original game plan and bought the G12 from the get-go. true it's size makes it difficult to stick in you short pocket, but there's a lot less fuss- not to mention the sharpness of the images are terrific. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Incredibly compact with large LCD viewscreen. I've only used Auto mode so far but face recognition and backlight compensation are impressive. Color saturation and glare reduction look as if a polarizing filter was in place. Often, people pictures look better than real life. Shutter lag time could be better.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I generally use DSLRs. Got this camera for it's RAW shooting capability combined with the small size (also liked the round the lens ring). So far I like the camera an have taken both candid and quick product shots of good quality. My only concern is that in RAW mode each frame takes forever to write on the card. Curiously, it's slow even In JPG mode : I have to give the shutter button a light press to revive the screen, which is otherwise stuck in photo review mode. I'll have to check all settings and also try the camera out with a SanDisk Extreme III (which I usually use an have had no speed Issues with) to see if issues persist...

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Best point n shoot/compact cam out now
Item.Review: Was looking for a quality pocket camera and the S95 fits the exact qualifications I was looking for. Excellent size and form-factor to slip into a pants pocket, great low light performance and daylight shots. RAW shooting and limited HDR features are a plus as well. Pop-up flash can be a bit problematic if giving your camera to someone else to take a shot and they don't expect it. Also, quality LCD screen that make photo playback great to look at on the camera. Have had no issues with running out of battery, but an extra one and large memory card is always recommended!

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Wow! The glowing reviews are accurate!
Item.Review: I had to buy this a bit sooner than I wanted when our aging cheap camera was lost and another broke. I got it based on Canon camera name/quality and top notch reviews for this and the S90. (The last Canon I bought was a 35mm film Rebel SLR.) Because of my immediate need, I didn't find any good discounts, and went with B&H because of reputation and past experience. I've only had the opportunity to use it for one real event so far (child's birthday), and my reaction is wow. The event covered three locations and included evening, night, sunlight, indoors, outdoors, and different lighting, and a few outdoor night shots for fun. For evening indoor shots, I had disabled the flash and forgotten that I had done so. I just assumed the camera did not need it, and it was taking superb pi ... ctures in ambient light w/o flash all evening. At night I turned on the flash and got adequate coverage in a very large room without light fall off at the far reaches of the image. I probably could've gone without flash then too, but 10 year old boys move too fast for that! HD video in a Taekwondo studio under flourescents and outdoors looked great, with good colors and resolution. But that sure ate up battery and memory, so be ready for that. Outdoor shots the next morning under sunlight were excellent. Shutter lag is very short if prefocus is used. Image transfer to my computer was snappy, at the rate of 2+ images / second over USB. I'm eager to try my favorite subject, mountain landscapes, in winter and summer, and try raw and HDR in that environment. For the regular family photos that I was able to try, it exceeded all expectations, and my expectations were high. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: The images are fine, but this camera have a weird ergonomic and an excess of buttons. The menus have too many options. Also the camera is not responsive at all. Slow focus, slow menus and slow shooting. Missed various moments. The battery won??t last a day of casual shooting. Have a dSLR camera and found they are way more easy to use than this camera. My wife and I prefered the practicality of the old SD800 camera. The camera is not very small and dont fit in a pants pocket.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Nice little camera with lots of features. I have been looking for a high end point and shoot to carry with me at all times after missing some priceless shots because I didn't have my Canon 40D with me. I wanted a camera that would shoot RAW (thou Aperture doesn't support it yet), could fit in my pocket, take videos and deliver stunning pictures. This camera does all that and more. Great in low light also!

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: This camera is amazing!!! Im a recreation photographer but like to do more than just pont and shoot i wanted a camera that had features of a point and shoot but also introduced me to the more complex features like adjusting apiture or adjusting the white balance. I love the color accent as well and the aging features the clarity is amazing. I have had many people comment on the sharpness of my photos. The size is fine and keep in mind im a large human with large hands. Having the new surface for better grip helps. This is my second cannon point and shoot. I'd recommend this camera to anyone. I get so much happiness when im using it. I will go out and spend hours taking a ton of photos and just experiment with all of the features as well as sharpening my photography skills at the s ... ame time. It is well worth the price and I am 100% satisfied with my purchase after months and months of research. I'm someone who will do a ton of leg work to make sure that I'm getting the top of the line product and I know very well that I achieved that this time with the cannon S95!! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Image quality, manual controls, size, build, HD video
Cons: HDR Mode
If you want a truly pocketable camera that gives you good image quality and full control over your photography, the S95 is an excellent choice.
I have closely compared this to the G12. Now, because my primary camera is a 50D, this is a back-up for when I don't want to lug a big camera and lenses around. You can't go wrong with either choice, but for me personally, the S95 was the one.
I took several pictures with both my 50D and the S95 and I was blown away of how similar the image quality is. I love all the manual controls that the S95 offers, in addition to being able to control them with the "ring" on the front of the camera. It's customizable, so you can adjust the zoom, aperture, ISO ... , exposure, etc, instead of scrolling through the menu each time to make changes.
The different scene modes are fun to play around with as well. You get a lot of camera for your money and I most certainly would suggest this to anyone in the market for a camera. If I have one complaint, it's the HDR feature. In my opinion, it doesn't work well at all. To get true HDR, you really need to take your images and use a software like PhotoMatrix or a plug-in for Photoshop. It's a first-time feature though on many cameras now, so like anything else, there is room for improvement. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Picture quality, quality feel
Cons: A little on the expensive side.
I purchased this camera three days ago and even though it is my "wife's camera" I have taken many pictures and videos. We have also looked at the S90 and of course it is an excellent camera...I use a Canon G11.
My wife noticed immediately the great picture quality particularly in low light without a flash. She sets it on automatic and it does a really great job. She also noticed (I did not mention this to her-came up with it on her own) that the camera body seems more tactile, easier to grip than the S90. Indeed the finish on the camera is different and really enhances the feel.
It also has an attachment on both sides of the camera so a neck strap can be attached. This may not seem like ... a big deal, but it really is - particularly when you are on vacation and want to keep the camera available without constantly holding it with one hand or putting it back in a case each time a picture has been taken.
My wife loves the small size and the flash is less obtrusive than that of the Nikon Coolpix 8000. For me, it is a little small in that my hands are bigger. I am ok with it but, it is not my first choice because of the size. It is my wife's first choice!
Item of interest; my G11 does not have HD and this camera does. The non HD video doesn't take a lot of memory card space, but the HD eats it up. I recorded about 30 seconds and the available picutre count went from around 2300 to about 1200. The video quality and the stereo sound are really nice, but it does eat a lot of space.
The display screen gets fingerprints easily because of the design, but that isn't a big deal in that it doesn't affect picuture quality. The flash does a good job for a small flash. The opitcal zoom is suficient and the digital zoom is fun to play with, but it isn't used that much.
The camera has a solid feel and appears to be constructed of metal. Good weight. No loose rubber tabs hanging from it. Feels like quality.
In summary, this camera provides great picutres in bright light and in low ... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: True photographer's point and shoot camera
Item.Review:
Pros: The best point and shoot picture quality available.
Cons: No fast continuous shooting mode.
I can't wait for this to come out so I can play with it!!! The image quality will be the same as the S90 in good lighting, but will surpass in low-light shooting. The images are incredibly crisp on the S90/S95 This is not an average person's camera, but it does have an auto mode. This camera has full manual mode for us advanced users, which is what photographers will be looking for. I believe that even this camera is better than the G11 mainly because of the 2.0 aperture(bigger opening to let light in through the lens) vs. 2.8 in the G11, so you can get brighter pictures in dim lighting. I am surprised that this only has 720pHD video instead of 1080p, but then I was surprised tha ... t the S90 and G11 only had standard 480p video. But overall quality, this is the best point and shoot pocket camera that you cam get expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I'm an avid photographer of 33 years' experience. I'm getting weary of dragging my DSLR and lenses everywhere, but even more weary of missing great photos when I do. The Canon S95 is the answer. I use this camera as both a backup to my DSLR and as a carry-around camera for every situation. I rarely leave home without it. This little powerhouse produces outstanding images: sharp, clear, and colorful. It's especially adept at producing ambient, low-light images. It shoots RAW images as well as JPEGs and can be set anywhere from fully automatic and fully manual and everywhere in between. The powerful little zoom will take care of nearly any shot from a landscape or cramped interior to a beautiful portrait. Perhaps my favorite feature is the customizable control ring that can be set for almos ... t any adjustment, including focus. I use mine for +/- EV settings. The camera's tiny stature, making it truly a pocket camera that you can take anywhere, shouldn't fool you: This camera is a powerhouse. And its lens is as sharp as a tack, which may not be true for other cameras, including the S95's successor. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Bought this camera to be our pocket and mobile option to our Canon T2i camera. And we are very impressed overall with it. Very easy to operate and, although being pocket, gives us a wide range of options and settings, like ISO, aperture, shutter speed, just like our reflex camera. Also, the pictures are very sharp and fully detailed. It has a fast and silent auto focus, possible also to do it manually. Shoots perfect in low-light conditions. It's body is in metal, making it very shock resistant. It's down sides are only the lack of a optical or even digital viewfinder and its short battery life, this being said, is highly reccomended the purchase of and addicional battery.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I love my DSLR camera, but sometimes a pocket camera is more convenient. The PowerShot S95 is exactly what I need: full control, outstanding image quality, and extreme pocket-size portability! If you don't want to sacrifice pro features like RAW, exposure compensation, or manual focus, with the S95 you don't have to. Also the automatic settings and program modes make this camera easy for anyone to take great pictures. I've only been using the S95 for a few weeks, but I am very impressed with it's usability, performance and the images it produces.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Great Lens in a Small Package
Item.Review: I bought this camera in order to have it with me always, unlike my DSLR, which is too big to take everywhere. It is the perfect size to tuck into a pocket, briefcase or purse. It takes surprisingly excellent photographs within its limitations [small sensor, no telephoto]. The results are so good that one of the photos I shot in RAW with the S95 and printed at 8x10 is going to be in a photo show in the spring of 2012. I use it to shoot RAW images in Av, Tv or P mode all the time and am happy with most of the results. I notice that it has noise in low light, but I would expect that in a camera of this type and it can be corrected in Photoshop or Lightroom. The autofocus seems sharp. The only real downside to the camera is that it is slow to take pictures, so you can't just snap away when you ... have an active scene. The LCD is very sharp and clear even in very bright, high altitude sunlight, which was something I was concerned about before using the camera. I bought a Schott glass screen protector for the camera and am very happy with that. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I use this product mainly while travelling and bought this as a replacement for heavy SLR gear. I didn't need the extra quality of an slr, but I needed to fit the camera in my pocket. This fits the bill, as I do keep changing setting a lot. I did not need zoom, but I can appreciate a fast lens. I got the s95 because I couln't get the S100. The s95 produces great colours though and I am happy with it. Battery life is also exceptional. I don't know how they do it, but it's nice not to have to recharge the battery all the time. Low light performance is ok, but I limited the auto ISO setting to max 800. Any more would be unusable. It could have been faster as well.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: The most import characteristic of camera is photo quality. Yes, maybe not very good display or bluetooth is important feature of camera for smb. If to compare cameras with similar price Canon PowerShot S95 of course will better, because another camers not provides such image quality. Another advantage of that camera is size. Another things are not critically important.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Superior image quality, loads of features.
Cons: Controls in the back leave little room for single-hand grip.
My first shot with the new camera was indoors with the built-in flash. Distance to subject matter in the room varied from 10 to 25 feet. Image detail was sharp and colors were vibrant - a stunning photo. This camera has loads of features including many options to control the focal length, focus and exposure. It's a toy to be coveted.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: This is a fantastic camera. There's really no other point and shoot camera to consider. Great quality photos, all the features you need and plenty more and it's small enough to fit into your pocket. This often takes the place of my DSLR and I use this all the time.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Much more than a point and shoot
Item.Review: I lost my camera on a plane and after talking to one of the folks at b h. They recommended this camera. I had had a new cannon elph300 and decided since I had to replace it I might as well upgrade It is excellent I am a garden designer and I mostly photograph landscapes. This camera is small and easy to stick into my pocket or bag when I am on a job site. It has excellent features for shooting plants as well as video if I need to video a site while making comments. It is so much more than a basic point and shoot I am interested in learning more about basic photography and how to use all of it's features. Dislikes The position of the pop up flash. And that the manual is on a disk not a book.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Great P&S Cam for DSLR users
Item.Review:
Pros: P&S version of a DSLR, high quality pics, great low light vid/pics, full manual control, bright and fast lens for size
Cons: Pricey, max 720p vid (can't toggle zoom during Rec), and no touch screen
Pros Fully customizable settings (aperture, shutter, wb, timer, flash, etc) Great low light pictures Great low light videos (up to 720p) Many useful settings (I really like the 'miniature mode') Sturdy build Mic audio is exceptional for such a small unit Bright LCD viewfinder Has two lanyard hookups on the corners for neck straps (tourist style) Fairly quick shots (startup to capture)
Cons Cannot toggle zoom in once Video is in 'Rec' mode Lacking touchscreen Menus can be tedious for new users - you get used to it after about 20 m ... in of use Battery life may be short depending on your settings (I have 3 batteries and it isn't a problem anymore) Built in 'pop up' flash could get jammed if you're finger is blocking it (it takes a a few uses to get used to this mechanism) No viewfinder (I would like to look through a lens rather than an LCD, call me old school, but I prefer this energy saving feature) Pricey (maybe you could use a RZ coupon, like I did- 12% off 349.99)
Overall, I like it as a secondary camera to my DSLR T1i. If I don't have the space to lug around my DSLR, this one is just fine. I also have a SonyT900, TX7, and TX100v. I have come to enjoy touch screen cameras, but hate how they get scratched up and lose their clarity from sliding in my pocket and camera pouch. Having this camera allows me to easily place a touchscreen protector without worry of damaging the viewfinder. I find that the Sony tx100v and the Canon s95 are great cameras in their own respect. I was stuck in the middle, but in the long run, if you enjoy true manual control of the camera, the s95 is the way to go. the Tx100v is a great for touchscreen lovers and quick capture pics without the need to go through adv. setting menus. If I had to take wedding pics and had to choose from these two cameras... I'd trust the s95. The quality of the pictures says it all. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Certainly the best camera you can fit in a pocket!
Item.Review:
Pros: Amazing features in a small size
Cons: The provided wrist strap is too loose to be useful
I've only had the camera for about a month now, but I've extremely pleased with how well it's performed. The manual control and dual control rings make this a great camera for someone like me who wants some of the advanced features of a DSLR but without all the heft. My previous point-and-shoot went everywhere with me (an Elph, which I also loved), from mountain bikes rides to snowboarding out west, and it never missed a beat. With the S95, I have the same size camera, but noticeably better results. Even in auto mode, the ability of the camera to switch into macro mode and adjust the focal length to blur the background is a welcome plus. I was thinking that I'd be adjusting the man ... ual settings all the time, but I've found that the camera reacts very well to varying conditions so that I only have to take over control when I really feel like getting creative. Or, I can just be lazy and use the many scene settings to get great results. One of the biggest surprises though, was the built-in "miniature" mode which provides a tilt-shift effect in still mode and a stop-motion mini effect in the video mode. This is also my first HD video camera, and I've been excited about the clips I've been able to get. Obviously, a point-and-shoot isn't going to be able to deliver the results of a DSLR, but a DSLR isn't going to fit in your pocket! For me, this camera is fantastic! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: The best that a point & shoot can handle
Item.Review: I use this camera to supplement the days I am not carrying around a DSLR. The camera fits in my pocket and I usually carry around a spare battery. The camera's macro feature is pretty useful, and of course, the camera's manual controls are a plus, which is also what the camera is popular for. Although, this is a great supplement, it's good to note that this is not a micro four-thirds or a DSLR, so make sure your expectations are of a point and shoot standard. With a point and shoot expectation, this camera is amazing. If your expectations are too high, you may be let down by limitations, like its DOF (due to sensor size), noise, etc. Also, I generally never zoom in under low light settings, as the Aperture suffers as you zoom in.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Although I own a digital SLR (and an old Pentax film SLR), I bought the S95 to use in situations where a larger camera is not practical, or where I want to use a compact camera for convenience. I plan to use the S95 while hiking, which is the main reason I bought it. Some friends of mine who are semi-professional photographers recommended the S95. I have had it just a little less that 2 weeks. So far, it has been great. It is easy to use, and the picture quality is wonderful. I especially like the fact that the user can make all sorts of adjustments to ISO, focal length, shutter speed to suit the conditions. It is compact enough that it can fit in a shirt or pants pocket. I will be carrying it in a case that fits on a belt or on a pack strap. I do sometimes prefer a viewfinder, as LCD's ... are hard to see in bright light, especially with polarized sunglasses. I suppose the camera is too small for both the viewfinder and and LCD display. This is only a minor problem for me. I'm looking forward to exploring more of the possibilities of this camera. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Good Image Stabilization; Good Image Quality; Easy To Use; Large Clear LCD; Small / Compact; Fast/accurate auto-focus
Big Canon fan for years. I was very happy with my S80, upgraded to the S95 over a G12 and couldn't be more pleased. Outstanding image quality. For the casual user, even a picky one, the S95's compact size makes it an always-carry. Though I love my 50D, its bulk is a handicap. Five star camera.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I am using this camera mainly for travel. It is so small and fit in my belt perfect. Now I understand why S95 is so expensive. Picture quality is amazingly. I set mine to auto all the time when I am lazy. This S95 picture quality many times rival mine Canon T2i. If you own any Dslr this little jewels is a good companion. Sometimes it even make me wonder,do I really need Dslar anymore:) The down side I really dont understand why Canon cut corner and not supply operating manual. They only give you starting manual basically tell you where to put battery and SD Card. Who doesn't know that? You can download manual on web site. I end up purchasing a book by Alexander S White to help me understand and learn more feature of Canon S95. Once again I will advise anyone look to buy best compact came ... ra Canon S95 is the one. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: lots of bang for lots of bucks
Item.Review: Because I did not like the image quality, some years ago I stopped using little digitals and got a Nikon SLR. But -- the Nikon, although excellent, is not something I am willing to carry with me everywhere I go. This thing is. The color is fine, the auto functions work very well, low light pictures (I dislike flash) are remarkable. There is exceptional control for when I want it. The best camera is the one you have with you. And this Canon is small and light enough to take everywhere.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: easy to use; pocket sized; well-focused pics
Item.Review:
Pros: good-quality images with ease of use
Cons: price
Purchased with little time to practice before vacation in Sweden. Practice was not necessary. This camera in auto mode has very discrete focus elements. Closeups with auto flash were excellent. Landscapes in dim light were well-balanced in fcal length and light. Indoor dim light at distances of more than 30 feet was the only difficult shot, but those shots are beyond the limits of the camera. In manual mode, without flash, time exposures were accepatble in dim indoor museum light. Camera a little pricy, but I am happy with the versatility of the camera, it's compact size.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I use this small camera for stills (AV mode is my favorite, followed by Manual) and home movies -- great HD movies. This size and form factor are terrific. Lens is wide and long enough-most small cameras are not wide enough for me. I have had a failure of the lens mechanism and am waiting to see whether the warranty will cover it. I hope so because it is my all time favorite small camera. I use a 20D for more SLR shooting.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Nice and handy with good quality
Item.Review: Bought this camera as a supplement to my DSLR camera. To be able to carry a camera for the unexpected, and for trips where I don't want to bring my DSLR. Nice and handy with good quality - exactly what I wanted and is exactly what I have got. The camera has a fast start, and has at nice and clear screen. Filming comes out with a good quality both in sound and pictures. Also easy to take pictures with low light. The pictures comes out in a nice quality, but with a low saturation. Batteries don't last that long.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: BEST pocket-size point & shoot I found.
Item.Review:
Pros: Easy To Use; Large Clear LCD; GREATclear LCD display; Nice Body Color; Good Image Quality; Good Image Stabilization; Good in Low Light; Small / Compact; Fast/accurate auto-focus
Cons: Poor location for flash; Macro focal-length averag; No Viewfinder
The Canon PowerShot S95 is a very nice compact pocket sized 10MP point & shoot camera. The suggested retail is a little pricey but I believe it's worth the price compared to other cameras in this category (i.e. compact, pocket-sized digital point & shoot). I bought my S95 as a bundle package which included many extras I would have bought sooner or later any way. So after I factor in the retail price of the camera with the added accessories, the over-all price for a camera bundle kit of this quality was fair and re ... asonable.
PROS: 1) It is a Canon camera ('nuf 'ced? - LOL). I've had GREAT luck with the results from all my Canon cameras I've owned and used cameras back to the days of SLR's and/or point & shoot film cameras. 2) Takes bright clear sharp (natural) colorful pictures in all lighting conditions and has a stunning LCD display (461K pixels) which is almost double the LCD pixel count compared to the average digital point & shoot providing incredibly crisp and sharp images. Most LCD displays on cameras in this category (that I looked at) typically averaged 230K pixel count. One of the reasons that make the 461 LCD pixel count important (to me) is when you take a picture, when viewing it on the LCD display, as you zoom in or out, the image on the LCD stays sharp and focused with little-to-no pixelization and virtually no motion blur with great contrast and nice dark blacks, providing a pretty decent sample of what to expect the full blown picture to look like when viewing it on your PC or viewing the final printed photo.
CONS: 1) My biggest complaint (so far) is the location of the pop-up flash. It is located on the top left front corner of the camera where I place my left index finger when preparing to take a picture (and where I would tend to guess is where most users also place their left index finger). However, a few times after the flash pops-up and you feel your finger in the way, it was surprisingly to me how easily I remembered that could happen again, and made a conscious effort to just move my left index finger towards the back of the left top corner and avoided the flash popping up hitting me finger. I would have also liked a view-finder (but NOT at the expense of increasing the actual camera size), larger "optical zoom" (even though so far, every picture I've taken using the zoom, came out amazingly clear and sharp with very little, if no pixelization at all) when blown up. Lastly, I would have liked the Macro focal length to be better. I looked at some other model cameras with a Macro focusing range from 0.4 in. – 1.6 ft. The S95 range is from 2.0 in. – 1.6 ft. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I have been holding of buying a compact for serveral years as I thought the image quality would not be worth it compared to a DSLR. This camera did not change that, but I admitt the usability and size is nice. In use, the controls on this compact is great. Putting it in manual mode its easy and fast to control the ISO/aparture/shutterspeed. I'm glad I did not buy the G12 with the slower lens. Images look pretty good when viewed small. This is a great camera that my girlfriend can borrow as she does not like using my Nikon D300.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Small / Compact; Large Clear LCD; Easy To Use; Good Image Quality; Nice Body Color
Great product. Came just as expected. Very happy. Had a great experience with buydig.com

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: The small, lightweight design makes this camera perfect for me to carry in my work bag or purse to grab shots of those random moments in the city. I love that it has the ability to go (almost) go completely manual, but the auto settings always give me great shots as well. I would recommend this camera to an amateur photographer who isn't ready to spend $1000+, or as a back-up, incognito camera for someone with more experience. Haven't had much need for the video as of yet, but will try it out on my vacation. The pop-up flash is a little oddly placed as it is located where you might put your left had to stabilize the camera when you take a shot. I got great night time shots of fireworks during the 4th of July weekend, which I was rather pleasantly surprised with.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Bright lens and full manual control
Cons: Nothing
For a point-and-shoot this camera will satisfy both the novice and the semi-pro. The best camera is the one you have with you and this Canon is small enough it can be with you all the time. It has great automatic features but can be switched into a fully manual mode so you control everything! Aperture, shutter speed, ISO, etc. Nice bright lens and exceptional picture quality.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: This is a beautiful little camera. Photos are noticeably better at wide end of the zoom, where the fast lens is crisp and accurate. Excellent, straightforward controls -- however some settings too easy to change accidentally. I'm most impressed by the video, having 24p HD video in such a tiny package is a game-changer.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Compared to the even lower cost Casio ES12, outdoor photos were comparable. Low light, however, this Canon is incredible for the price. Hardly needed flash; important since many of my shots are during church services. The HD video is even more remarkable in low light, and the sound quality is fine. Easier to use than the Casio, I also like the option to focus myself with the outer ring. Be sure to read the PDF manual on the (included) disk. The paper one is not enough. I am still working on the focus. [...]

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: not much zoom, but a lot of quality
Item.Review: I am still learning, but I do some macro and some landscapes and street photography, all mainly outside in natural light. It excels in macro and it has amazing low light capability. It gives you a lot of control. It is small and inconspicuous and easily pocketable. The zoom is a real drawback. The battery is a minor drawback.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I have owned so many digital point and shoot cameras including Nikon, Lumix, Panasonic and various Canons including G11. I love G11 though. it's just too heavy and big for my purse. I like to take every day life impulsive photos. S95 just great for everything. Perfect for automatic point and shoot, exactly same photo quality as heavy G11. but super light and compact! So many different & cool scene options. love vintage, miniature, poster effect etc... also I can change functions manually depending on what kind of photo I want to take. this is just THE GREATEST small digital point and shoot camera ever so far! love it!

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: when the BH sales associate told me that it was worth every penny and that it was probably the best point and shoot camera on the market, I was excited yet hesitant to see what this camera had to offer. In the past I've tried Sony, Nikon, Pentax and other Canon products, and have always felt that Canon had an edge in terms of practicality and quality (not necessarily coolness). But taking this camera and trying it out on my vacation was excellent. The camera shoots in and displays photos with HD quality, and the colors and images are sharp and vibrant. It has a motion sensor, so that people without steady hands like me, usually always have crisp images. The difference in my last camera (Canon SD900) are very surprising, having a wow factor. It does have a lot of options (including ma ... nual settings) that have yet to be tried out, but many of the effects that you look for (such as fish eye, or low light conditions) are all included in this camera. Video and sound quality are equally amazing, and the overall ease of use is worth every penny. Because of the range of options and capabilities, it takes time to absorb the range of this camera. The user manual comes on a cd and is 150+ pages. But purely based on photo quality and ease of use, this camera is a definite buy for those who are serious about their photography but not serious enough to buy an expensive SLR. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: You cannot get a better pocket camera than this one. The lens is very fast (2.0), which allows you to take pictures in low light. The high ISO also works very well (up to 1600 is great for my taste). It has all the manual controls and a very handy control ring around the lens. I wish the battery would last a bit longer (200 shots is the stated battery time), but it should be enough for a day out. For a camera of this size, you cannot beat it.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: This P&S is Awesome! I use the S95 to take pictures and videos at various events and just for fun. While I am not a professional photographer, the S95 turns me into one. It automatic mode is incredible producing flawless pictures in any environment. You will not find a P&S that is better. I promise. My S95 recently spent time at the 2011 New York International Auto Show and I could not be happier with the results. Things that are great: 1. Takes Incredible Pictures 2. Allows you to take full control with manual controls 3. Many great built in effects 4. Stylish Look 5. User friendly interface/buttons & controls 6.POCKETABLE!!! Things that are not so great: 1. For the price...it should come with a basic case at the very least. I ended up purchasing a Boblbee Aniara case for ... my S95 and it is perfect! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Picture quality, versatility, manual settings, artistic photo modes, macro function, video mode, size
Cons: Inconvenient location of pop-up flash, battery life, sometimes confusing controls
I purchased this item for general photography when my 7D would be too hefty or to conspicuous for the environment. I work often in developing countries as a physician and hoped it would be suitable for pathology photos and training purposes as well as snapshots on day travels. The camera has exceeded my expectations. The photographs are high quality and the macro function very useful. It took some time to learn the controls, but it has the flexibility I needed for multiple purposes as well as great functions I was not aware of for artistic use. I compared it to my 7D for night photog ... raphy (<30 second exposure) and found that , sadly, I liked the photos from the S95 better the majority of the time. Although I was reluctant to pay the hefty price for a point and shoot camera, it is the best purchase I have made in years. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: S95 - Canon Black PowerShot 10 Megapixels Digital Camera review
Item.Review:
Pros: Large Clear LCD,Good in Low Light,Good Image Quality,Good Image Stabilization,Small / Compact,Easy To Use
I bought this cam because my old Canon Ixus40 (2004) is out of time. I read several reviews, test artciles and checked some comments on youtube. Finally I went to a store to check it out in real. I just gonna mention the spots of bother, because any further comments on the picture quality and so on will be just a repetition of all the previous comments and articles. In one sentence: Image quality is very good, manual options are great, you can change aperture, ISO, shutter speed and whitebalance manually.
1. I just can recommend everybody at first to check out the handling of the cam. The scroll wheel is partly hidden inside the casing and the force you need to ... rotate the wheel into the next position is unusual high. With freshly creamed hands like on the beach, or sweating skin during summer it might become an issue.
2. During the first test-shots I tested the flash and I must say the mechanism to pop it out is quite strong. It can easily lift your left index-finger while holding the cam, so the first time it happend to me I wanted to decrease my finger-pressure on the case at the flashs place. But in the same moment I felt how the cam was turning already to fall down. I grabed it in that second a little bit stronger preventing it to slip out of my hands. So I think this can easily happen to someone who is not familiar with that cam and wants to shot in the automatic mode. You must be cautious about using the flash.
3. Unfortunately the design-guys have changed the side-edges to a rounded shape. That's why you cannot place the cam vetically on a table for example to take a pic of yourself by using the self-timer. It falls forward on the objective (because of its weight). So you need to stabilize it by putting something slim enough between the objective and the table (a nokia 6300 fits quite perfect;) ).
4. The strap to secure the cam to your wrist doesn't have any "zipper" to tight the strap. It remains loose. My old Ixus40 does have this "zipper" on the strap. You can tight it very well to the wrist and you can even drop the cam from your hand by holding your arm down. The strap stays on your wrist-that's how it should be always!
Despite from these 4 points, I like the cam and I gonna keep it, because I cannot find any different cam, which makes so nice pictures by being so slim. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: The Camera User Guide not included
Item.Review:
Pros: Large Clear LCD; Good in Low Light; Good Image Quality; Nice Body Color; Good Image Stabilization; Small / Compact
This is a great camera! I bought mine from Adorama and it didn't include the owners manual. The manual can be downloaded as a PDF file- all 192 pages, and printed on 8 1/2 by 11 inch paper (one sheet per page). I didn't buy a compact camera intending to lug a reprinted manual the size of a very large book.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I bought the camera initially for a trip to France and it??s main use will be as an underwater camera (just bought the Ikelite housing). During the trip, the usual pocketability of the camera allowed me to take it everywhere. And it really means everywhere. I ride bicycles a lot, and having a camera I can really pocket makes a huge difference. This is a very compact camera, without anything really protruding (except just a tad of the lens). Of course it is a great camera, technically: RAW support, fast lens (only at it??s widest though), decent wide-zoom ratio, manual exposure controls and manual focus. The front ring is very comfortable, for manual focus (I don??t use it much really), and I loved it for changing amongst lenses (you can use it to step through zoom levels identified as va ... rious lens lengths). The rear ring is ok too, allowing you to cycle through the different settings. Menus and usability is very good, at least for me. I really like Canon point and shoot men system, but it is a bit of a personal thing. You should try for yourself. But out of the many cameras I have tried, Canon is good an easy to use. At least once you get used to it, you can be rather fast at changing settings (which is important on a point and shoot). The feel of the camera is just right. The texture is very good. You feel it is a sturdy camera with very hight quality finishing. It also feels great (and securely gripped) in your hand. The camera is very fast at being ready to shoot. It takes very few seconds to be ready for action, lens extended et al. This is very important in a pocket camera. Regarding image quality, you can surely look up samples and more technical reviews elsewhere. Even though it??s low light performance has improved a lot (compared to mi SD750 for example), I still find small cameras to be disappontingly noisy. My biggest disappointment though, is the lack of a fast 2.8 setting at medium length lenses, like 35mm. I don??t like wide angles at all, so I get hit a lot by never being able to use the fastest aperture. Overall, it??s a great little camera. I truly believe if you are going to own more than one camera, get the smallest, and the biggest .I have a 5D and the S95. In betweens are just too bulky and not flexible enough. If you are considering the S95, also think about the Olympus ZX1, which is also very nice, and offers you a faster lens with better apertures all around. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I use this to throw in my purse or diaper bag to have on hand to take pics of the kiddos when I don't feel like bringing my DSLR with. I like the size and the fact that I can shoot in manual if I choose to. The picture quality is really good in my opinion. I also like that it has HD video to capture videos on the go as well. The shutter lag exists, but to be expected with a point and shoot. I am very happy with my purchase so far!

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Always wanted a Nikon SLR, and multiple lenses. Didn't have 3 grand, and it requires lugging around a large piece of equipment at times when it's not wanted. So, I decided to start small, and I was amazed what a small camera can do now. Bought a pouch to carry it and protect it when out hiking. Took pics of 3/4" flowers with no problem, no blurr. I shake alot, but this camera has no problem getting a good pic. I like the sequential shooting mode so I can just keep firing. 15x zoom in the 4:3 aspect ratio mode gets me in tight for most pics. Very few times I need more. Used the video at a softball game, and no blurr. just great picture and sound. The super vivid mode can get some nice pics in the right situation, but most of the time just looks bad. Experiment. I like that I can change the ... aspect ratio to one of 5 different shapes so I don't have to edit, or crop photos. I just compose with the best size, and shoot. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: The S95 is a great vacation camera for everyone above the age of 12. Several of the cameras modes require a tripod; but that is no complaint,as this is one of the most versital cameras I have ever used. I own a total of 8 Cannon cameras and lenses but I will be using the S95 for nearly any project from now on. If all your photos are 8X10 or smaller this is your camera. The only caveat I have is the small size of some of the controls, I have large fingers and must look to find some buttons.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Compact, easy to use, and great pictures
Item.Review: This camera is small and light enough to always bring along, and takes high quality pictures... good enough that I won't feel bad about not bringing the big heavy Canon 60D + lenses on serious hikes or when we're travelling light. Of course, it isn't nearly as good as the SLR, but the quality is very good for the size, weight and cost. No regrets on this purchase!

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Perfect point-and-shoot with all the manual options you might need. I use this camera for work (location scouting) taking 300-500 photos a day. It's light weight, fast, easy to use and takes great shots. If you shoot in natural light, it's great in low light and has a nice little feature called i-contrast for fixing those sharp shadows created on bright days. Downsides: I really don't like the soft wear you get with the camera. Image browser is super slow. I use canon photo stitch which is average.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I have not owned or used the camera long enough to give a full review. There are plenty out there, and I read many to decide to buy. But I can say that as an Industrial Designer and user of many DSLRs, the s95's quick manual controls are very nice to use. The lens ring combined with the back panel dial makes for very fast and intuitive adjustment of aperture and shutter speed. The big bright screen reflects those adjustments and then you shoot...it's sweet. On another note I bought this model over others for its compactness, and I am not disappointed. I've owned a series of ELPH Canons, since the first APS Elph in the late '90s. This s95 is about the size of that first ELPH, it fits in its case. I bought a new case from case logic for around $8 that is cordura and has an external pocket th ... at holds an extra battery and sd cards. Anyway, so far I'm very happy with it. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Small, fast, settings, picture quality, flexibility, miniature mode (tilt shift affect)
Cons: pricey, HD video only does 720p at 24 frames
I wanted a camera that would have the same type of settings I have with my T2i and this was it. I love the fact that I can manipulate the settings to what I want. Picture quality is superior than to other Point and shoot cameras. t is handy to have when you don't feel like lugging around my SLR gear. I would agree that the price is a little high but as stated earlier I like the flexibility of this camera. Its a nice little video camera too. Overall I would recommend this camera to people that have experience in photography and prefer to be in control of their pictures. This may be an intimidating camera to someone that wants just a b ... asic point and shoot. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: great camera for taking pictures in low light
Item.Review:
Pros: Taking pictures in low light
Cons: Flash position, memory card is not included
Nice lightweight camera that takes great pictures in low light. Video is nice clear with very good sound. I believe it is the best of the point and shoot cameras on the market today.
It would be nice if the did something about the position of the flash. Pops up in the very spot I hold the camera. Also it would be nice if they included Adobe Photoshop Elements instead of Cannon's software.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Small and capable
Cons: May not need my DSLR in all cases ;-)
I have been taking photograph for over 50 years both film and digital and this is by far the best point and shoot camera I have owned. I recently visited San Francisco and carried the Canon S95 camera in my pocket to be able to take pictures without hauling a large DSLR around.
I was amazed at the quality clarity and color reproduced with this camera. This is not a DSLR, but the results are about as close as you can get for a camera with the zoom range of the S95. The low light capability of this camera is the best I have seen with minimal noise in pictures taken ar high ISO settings.
A bonus is that the S95 can record in full HD with stereo sound. The S95 also can be operated in several program ... modes or in aperture, shutter or fully manual modes. The vivid color programmed mode can create some very punchy color pictures. I also find the built in flash small but very capable for the size of the flash.
This camera also has excellent close-up macro mode.
If you like the quality of a DSLR camera and want a backup camera or just don't want to haul the DLSR around, this is a camera you need to consider. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Ease of use, extremely versatile. Great for the rank amateur or the seasoned professional (like me!)
Cons: A bit pricey, but you get what you pay for.
Took my new Canon S95 that my wife gave me for Valentine's Day out for a spin to Blue Sushi, Gloria's, and Pappasito's restaurants to test its abilities in low light situations, which is the REAL test of a point and shoot's ability. Almost any camera can shoot something halfway decent in daylight.
My evaluation: Get right to it: THIS camera is the BOMB.COM: 10 megapixel, larger sensor (the secret weapon), capability to shoot RAW+JPEG at the same time, 80-3200 ISO (yes, 3200 that is NOT a custom function), can take High Capacity (HC) HD cards and can be used in full manual mode for photographers who want full creati ... ve control, PLUS Macro ability! Adjustable white balance, including custom white balance control AND (get this) an UNDERWATER white balance setting (assuming you put it in a housing of some sort...lol).
Plus, exposure AND flash compensation, and HD video, too!
There are other "point and shoot" style cameras out there that have many of the same functions, but they aren't of the same compact design. The others are bulkier, heavier and have the mass of a pint-sized toaster. The S95 is sleek and compact and is about the size of my iPhone...actually a bit shorter and about the same weight.
I LOVE LOVE it!
As guys are wont to do: Let's put a number on this thing. Scale of 1 to 10, 1 being the low end and 10 being the "buy this thing if you want absolute greatness"....I give this camera an 11 for its ability to do it all in a compact and sleek package. Looking for a great point and shoot? The Canon S95 is the answer.
On Facebook, look up my phot review at: Took my new Canon S95 that Susan gave me for Valentine's Day out for a spin to Blue Sushi, Gloria's, and Pappasito's to test its abilities in low light situations, which is the REAL test of a point and shoot's ability. Almost any camera can shoot something halfway decent in daylight.
My evaluation: Get right to it: THIS camera is the BOMB.COM: 10 megapixel, larger sensor (the secret weapon), capability t ... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Totally inconsistent color from shots taken of same subject within seconds. Short battery life. Not impressed with image quality. Have had better results from small cheaper point & shoot cameras, including other Canon models.
Item.HelpfulCount: 0 out of 1 found this review helpful.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: A good point and shoot alternative to a DSLR
Item.Review:
Pros: Lots of features and fast 2.0 lens
Cons: Not much
Lots of flexible features, incl. fast 2.0 lens. Settings take a little time to get used to, but the picture quality, even in low light is the reason I purchased this camera. It meets my expectations. The flash settings are a bit clumsy, but if you know what you are doing or what you want from the picture, you can manually set the flash to meet your needs. If battery life is a problem, as is often stated, I have not run into yet. I have a 16 GB, Class 6 memory card and that is enough to get me through a few days. I do shoot in Raw and jpg for picture quality and 16 GB is enough to get me through 2 days.
If you are an advanced amateur photographer, this is a good second camera behind your DSLR.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Great point and shoot with HD video
Item.Review: This camera is equivalent to G12, the great canon point and shoot, but it's more practical because of its size. Manual features work perfectly fine for advanced control of shooting, ISO goes up to 3200 and it makes great video. And also it's pretty and light. I recommend to all users for high quality photo and video in a very compact camera.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Picture Quality; Features; Compact; Manual Controls; HD video
Cons: Pricey; Annoying pop up flash
Canon S95 has 10 megapixels. IT has excellent image stabilization and loads of useful features. So many in fact, that I have not tried them all out yet.
